reviewText:
There isn't much I can say about Bastion that hasn't been said already. The art is pretty, the music wonderful and the narrator amazing.
You play as the Kid, trying to find out what happened to your world which suddenly crumbled into pieces in an event called the Calamity. Along the way you meet a couple of other survivors and gather them at the bastion, a flying fortress that has the power to make everything right again. The NG+ is useful if you want to see both endings of the game because there is only one automatic save slot and the no sweat mode was a salvation for me ( I died more times by falling off the edge than by actual monsters - except perhaps the pesky anklegators).

TL;DR: Play this game if :
You love clicking your mouse.
You love stalker narrators with raspy voices.
You like falling off cliff edges and dying.
You are a masochist with all 10 shrine idols invoked for impossible-to-beat who-knows-wheres.
Even if you don't like any of these things, play this game. It's brilliant.

reviewText:
Have you ever asked or been asked if video games are art? Look no further than this game to seek your answer. This game's beautiful art-style and stunningly moving (and reactive) narration is so powerful it will bring tears to your eyes, and is by far the best written game I have ever played (and I prefer games that focus on storytelling).

Don't let the cute art-style or isometric perspective fool you - this is a tragedy set in a post-apocalyptic world (that's right, a post-apocalyptic world featuring every colour of the rainbow) that will have you battling both your conscience and fate through a linier narrative. The battle system may be simple, but there is enough variety of both melee and ranged weapons, stat-boosting tonics and difficulty-enhancing totems that you will find exactly the kind of game you are looking for, regardless of your tastes. Unusually for a linier story replayability abounds as this game features a 'New Game Plus' mode, 'Score Attack' mode, in-game challenges and multiple endings to the 9-hour story for you to sink your teeth into.

If ever you have bought a game out of curiosty or on the word of another, let it be this one - you will not be disappointed.

reviewText:
Bastion is a very stylized isometric action game in which you play a young character who finds himself awaken shortly after the apocalypse. As you explore, the world fills in around you. Over the course of the game, you pick up a variety of weapons, powers, abilities, and even penalties you can equip to give yourself better rewards, all while working your way through the areas and story.

Bastion's strengths are three main areas: first, how it tells the story. The actions of the player are narrated by a fantastic voice actor, providing a feeling of having the tale be told as you play it out, which is very unique among games. Secondly, it has an amazing soundtrack, which I don't know exactly how to describe - maybe Electronic Folk? Anyway, it absolutely has one of the best soundtracks of any game I've ever played. Finally, the story itself, which I obviously don't want to spoil in the review, so I'll leave you to that.

There's a fair amount of replayability and challenges to complete if the player is so inclined - I personally chose to play through once and enjoyed it as that. At any rate, the most important thing is this: buy this game, and when you do, buy the soundtrack.

reviewText:
Bastion will forever live as one of the best games I have ever played. With a beautiful art and animation direction surrounded by a glorious and trully brilliant score, sound, and narration, Bastion grips the senses from the very moment you wake in a ruined floating city. As the entire experience is brought together with a powerful and driven story with unforgettable characters, it undoubtedly stands as a groundbreaking isometric role-playing game and an impressive debut game from Supergiant Games.

Not only does the main story impress, but every weapon training level provides an entirely different style of combat not only with the respective represented weapon but the very grounds upon where you must prove your tactical prowess is carefully crafted and detailed to offer an eye-catching and grip-tightening hold on the challenger. Similarly, the four trips to Who-Knows-Where pit you against wave after wave of enemies to test one beyond their normal gaming limits and bring one to a peak of their reaction-timing and accuracy mastery. Bastion includes 24 Steam Achievements that will each take the player to the edge of their gaming ability and focus. It will most certainly build a better gamer out of you. Bastion is absolute gaming perfection.

With every brutally powerful enemy and cryptically beautiful scene, The Kid must traverse a broken sky for the materials needed to bring life back to his dying city of Caelondia and undo the damage wrought by The Calamity. As The Kid travels, he'll discover more than he bargained for surviving in vicious wildernesses, salvaged from fractured villages, and sacrificed to melted mountains. He'll face beasts of the wild, the warriors of The Ura, and even be tested by gods above to save the very fabric of reality, all the while unravelling the secrets of not only the city's fate, but his own past as well as his future.

reviewText:
Bastion is one of a kind and you owe it to yourself to play this game.
A charming hack and slash/RPG, one of those games that you will never forget, for a particularly reason or not.

Every character, every item, has a story and a function in the world.
And they are all explained by the narrator, whose voice work is simply fantastic. A new way of narrative in games.
What about the soundtrack? Remarkable piece of work.

In the end this is all about the Kid's journey. How it will end up, it's up to you.

reviewText: Bastion is one of the best new games I've played in a long while. I guess technically it is an action-RPG, but not in the traditional sense (for example, it's very short and you only gain 10 levels maximum). But it's not even really the gameplay that is the main attraction anyways (at least not for me) - rather, it's the unique world you get to visit during those few hours. The world is visually beautiful and the soundtrack is amazing, but the main draw that keeps you engaged is the smooth-voiced narrator that tells the story of everything you do as you do it. It's hard to explain the concept properly since it is unprecedented in gaming, so all I can really say is check it out and see for yourself. The game itself is not very hard, so pretty much anyone should be able to finish it (there are also various options more experienced players can enable if they wish to make the game harder). I can't say enough good things about Bastion - it is practically a clinic in game design. Get it!

reviewText:
Oh my gracious sauce, it is time to review Bastion.

Let's first begin by talking about the gameplay. While it is not extraordinary, it is very solid and I enjoyed it like I enjoy a rich potato salad.  You can carry two weapons in your main loadout as well as one special move or skill. As you progress through the game you will find more weapons and your options will increase dramatically.  Experimenting with the different weapons to find the playstyle you like best is great fun. There is also an upgrade system for these weapons which allows you to experiment even further. All super sauce.

You play through many different levels as you defeat enemies and collect shards.  This is where the great visuals are shown off.  They are crazy delicious. Ridiculously good. They did great work on the art style of this game and it pays off.  The music is also fantastic.

The biggest flaw of Bastion is that the main game is shorter than most. However, the replay value is boosted by optional challenges and endurance tests.  The difficulty level is also quite tame, but they allow the player to make the game harder and recieve more EXP by playing on harder difficulties.  It is up to the player to add more pasta sauce to the game if the length and difficulty do not satisfy.

What I believe to be the most defining part of Bastion is the narrator who narrates all that the main character does in the game as you control him.  It is a very unique and fresh idea that made me say Holy iguana lungs
date: this idea is pretty sauce!". The voice actor for the narrator is also excellent and his voice is quite godlike and very fitting.\n\nOverall
recommended: this game is definitely a slam dunk worthy of a top 10 special on ESPN.  The music

reviewText:
So, there are loads of reviews that go into great depth as to what makes this game a great buy. I shall focus solely on one aspect that I think needs highlighting.



When you pick up a health potion whilst already containing the maximum amount of potions allowed, it's not wasted and fills your health.



You wouldn't think this is a big deal, but so often you have to pause, load your health potion, use it, unequip it, acquire new potion. Rinse. Repeat. This game does away with that and it's awesome!

reviewText:
Crisp, detailed artwork. From the clouds rolling over the map, to the in-game items, everything is thoughtfully crafted and coherent. A single aesthetic for the entire game scales from little elements to full-fledged splash pages.

The music does well to pair with the artwork. There's no let down. As much mood is created visually, there is equally fine musical pieces that create the sensations of adventure and tension in all the right places.

There's a major cool" factor with the audio in general. The gruff but smoothly delivered voice-over fits the writing styles comfortable brevity. I never felt tired of sitting through narration. It was quick
recommended: but stylized to keep the entertainment flowing. The tunes mix atmosphere and raw
hoursPlayed:
bluesy-western sounding guitar. Like our hero was born "cool" right out of the womb.

How easy it would've been to fudge these artistic choices and end up with something cheesy. Bastion is coherent on all fronts visual and auditory.

As for the mechanics and gameplay? I think they play second fiddle. Passable by all means - nothing seemed to be lacking

reviewText:
An isometric quasi-rpg with satisfyingly repetitive combat, and an impressive new game plus.

Still, Bastion is more than that. Bastion is all about its narrative, through music and spoken word, the true soul of this game lies in its somber self-awareness as it cooly reveals itself to you by way of storytelling.

Great port, great on KBM or gamepads, and won't break your wallet. Buy this game.

reviewText:
Bastion is Supergiant Games’ debut title and oh what a debut it is. It has pretty simple combat. There is a variety of weapons, tonics that can gives you buffs and a basic but effective counter/dodge system.

What really sets Bastion apart as a debut is the art direction and storytelling. Bastion has the most wonderful soulful and soothing narration, incredible and varied music and beautiful hand painted scenery that I've ever seen in a game.

To anyone that says games can't be judged as art, play Bastion and I swear it will change your opinion completely.

reviewText:
I like Bastion and I recommend it but it's probably not for everyone.

The levels are generally well done but choosing the right weapons etc. is quite important which can lead to some frustrating trial-and-error (and a bit of grinding to level-up the weapons too perhaps)

The narration and story are going to be loved by some and not others.  I started-off really enjoying it but it does get a bit wearing after a while - there's a change of tone from detatched observation to an almost I told you so - harder than you think"-ness about it and it REVELS in revealing that you're nowhere near the end when you think you might be;0

It's mostly a charming and enjoyable action game tho and so I kinda point a thumb upwards here..."

reviewText:
-Quick review-
Bastion is a good game, has excellent music, plays like a dungeon crawler, and has a great story that you can complete in maybe 5-6 hours.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yBqb-l5dS0A

-Detailed breakdown review-
Story: you play as one character known simply as “the kid”, the kid is trying to collect shards to bring back the Bastion. The Bastion was a place everyone agreed to meet if there was an emergency. Through great story telling, a great narrator and many twists and turns in this puzzle-piece-world you find yourself sitting back and enjoying a story being told with some good natured humor as well.

Music: The game has extraordinarily good music, a video game itself needs to have good music, or else it takes away from the experience, but bastion has very suitable music and a soundtrack that I personally wouldn’t mind downloading.

Play-Style: You can swing a hammer, shoot a bow, poke with a stick, go click-happy with double revolver pistols and many other choices of weapons and combinations. Pick your favorite weapons; upgrade them at the forge to make yourself into one lethal mean killing machine.

Achievements: I tend to play video games like I’m in a race to complete them, so I have played through the game’s story about 4 times now gathering achievements. In addition to playing through that many times, it took me only 21 hours. (Such as 02/12/14)
The achievements themselves aren’t overwhelmingly challenging, which is good sometimes you just want a relaxing game, if you’re going for a 100% completed game, this one is very doable, look up the guides for the harder achievements, and prepare yourself for a some-what challenging experience

Price: I consider price by how much time I’ve put into a game, how enjoyable it was, and if it’s replayable. Full price for Bastion is 14.99 at this time. I would suggest waiting for a 50% or 75% sale before purchasing. But I would highly recommend this game to anyone who’s looking for something new to play.

------Edits and updates------
Edit/Update May 27, 2016:
added link to my new/updated Bastion YouTube Review.

reviewText:
For some reason, it took me 3 separate attempts over a few years to actually sit down and play this game all the way through. After finally finishing the game, I have to admit I'm not quite sure what held me back on my first 2 attempts because Bastion is a truly great game. It succeeds in nearly every way.

Probably the most noteworthy and distinct aspects are its narration and visuals, both of which players will notice almost immediately. The narration guides along not only the story, but the gameplay as well, which - when coupled with the source of the narration - provides a more intimate and closely-felt experience. Much of the game's worldbuilding and lore is also developed through the narrator, with his very human, down-to-earth, and often heartfelt voice acting. Characters and their backstories are also developed in this way, and the story being progressed in this manner turns out to be more intricate and poignant than it would seem at first. Worldbuilding also takes place quite literally as the world is built before your eyes as you move along an area. This decision to have the setting come to life as you go does wonders for the feel of the game; it's a design choice (and in a way, a mechanic) that is entirely unique and refreshing and elevates the aesthetics of the game to another level.

Also worth mentioning is Bastion's incredible soundtrack. Its varying tracks fit the moods of different moments and locations exceptionally well. The music of Bastion is instrumental (heh) in creating the right atmosphere as it complements the narration and aesthetics to make a truly powerful experience. One track in particular caught my attention the instant the female vocals rang out, and I almost stopped playing just to appreciate the chillingly beautiful song.

The actual gameplay of Bastion is probably actually its weakest point, and that's only because the rest of the game is on another level. The gameplay is actually quite good, with satisfying combat that holds more depth than it would initially seem. It's not amazing as Bastion's other aspects, and it doesn't really do anything new, but it works just fine for the game and still provides for a fun experience. There is also a fair amount of replayability, which is always a plus in my book.

With a gorgeous soundtrack and aesthetics, solid gameplay, and top-notch narration, Bastion easily deserves its spot in the hall of fame for indie games.

8.5/10

reviewText:
Bastion is an RPG top down game created by an indie developer, Supergiant Games (creators of Transistor as you know). The game's setting is in Caelondia, a war torned atmosphere left by after the war between Uras and Caels (I tried to remember the plot but this is a close one as I can remember). You will play as The Kid, an amnesiac warrior who cannot remember the past and tried to unravel. This game's dialogue have a minimalistic feel because the protagonist doesn't talk and same thing as support characters as well. The narrative voice acting, oh man, the best voice acting I have ever heard in my whole entire life. The musical scores are top notch, especially when you are in the dream sequence and every region you explore. The graphics are eye candy and visually stunning, the art style is immersively well done, the animations are well executed. The combat system is solid and fluid, you can have 2 weapons to carry and you can change the weapons if you can find The Arsenal during missions or before starting the mission. You have abilities to choose from to eliminate enemies with ease. The Forge lets you upgrade your weapons but you need a particular parts to upgrade the weapon. The Distillery lets you drink any potions you like, it gives you the benefits for your stats but also there are side effects or negative effects in it. The enemy A.I. are smart and tough. Every enemy you encounter needs a proper strategy because they have different attack patterns and weaknesses, so it's best not to mash buttons to win. If you want a challenge(it's an optional), you can turn them on by building the Shrine and enable any idols you like to have. I recommend everyone to use a controller, the controls are tight and responsive, no problem. There are 2 endings you can choose from, so it's better not to spoil for everyone (for the sake of not to ruin their experience).

+ Pros+ Narrative Voice Acting and Musical Scores
+ Graphics and the art style of the game
+ Variety of enemy A.I. behaves and attack patterns differently
+ Tons of weapons you can use, suited for your playstyle
+ Replayability (New Game Plus available after finishing the game)


- Cons- Keyboard and Mouse are not recommended unless you don't own a controller or don't like using a controller
- Not many varieties for main objective (finding a same life crystal to restore the Bastion)

In this game's honest review, I enjoyed playing this game, just relax playing this game while the narrative is soothing my ears. The graphics, the musical scores, jnarrative voice acting, solid combat system and challenges that made this game's biggest strength. But there is a lack of variety during missions like finding a life crystal, encountering NPCs, it's a tiresome experience for me. I recommend you to buy this game during Sale because it's $2.50 (just in case if someone doesn't like the game, correct me if the price point is wrong). It's a solid recommendation.

reviewText: This game deserved an overwhelmingly positive reviewEven if Bastion is short (just a few hours <11hrs' mine>, depending on how many challenges you're keen on passing with a gold medal rating) it's one of the few games in which the New Game+ (rewinding the whole adventure but keeping the endgame resources) was just as much fun as the first playthrough. The content might be identical, but you've probably missed out on a few platforms the first time around, so you'll have the opportunity of discovering them and testing out your untapped weapons as well.\nThe storytelling is unique and relaxing. While you do work fighting off enemies, the narrator gives you the lowdown. The world you explore is fragmented and broken, but the visual element of the game is gorgeous. Most importantly, Bastion's music ties everything together. I can still hear the bluesy guitar line and the hurt voice of a character you meet early in the game.\nA game you should buy 10/10 !

reviewText:
Typically when a game's length comes into question, it's because of triple-digit hours on one save file. However, Bastion is one of those rare flames that petered out too quickly. Whether this complements the strong gameplay and story or serves as a complaint of an unfinished product is up to the reader. I am certain of this, though: some developer somewhere is scribbling down ways to turn Bastion's novel approach to RPGs into a multi-million dollar project.

Few games can claim that they revolutionized the industry, and when they do, it's the one simple, novel idea that makes the mark. For Bastion, that's the velvety narrator who comments on nearly every aspect of gameplay. Fall off the landscape? He's got something to say about it. Thwart a boss without getting nicked? Expect a new piece of dialogue. Choose any two weapons? Prepare to methodically run through every combination of equipment.

But he does more than simply comment. The narrator tells the story from the perspective of a weathered, rustic old man who's made mistakes and bears the burden of regret. At the same time, he speaks of The Kid as a champion–someone who can make things right. And that's where you come in: as The Kid, you have the opportunity to fix a sort of man-made apocalypse called the Calamity. Finding survivors along the way, The Kid has to restore power back to Bastion, the protagonists' headquarters.

By finding crystals through linearly explored areas, The Kid grants Bastion energy, and buildings for some reason. Players have the illusion of choice when deciding which structure to erect, each of which grants some sort of ability or perk. The Arsenal, for example, allows the player to choose which weapons he'd like to equip, as well as a super power. Alternatively, the Shrine invokes the gods, which can make the game more difficult with a slight boost to experience and money; it's worth mentioning that the ways in which a player may increase difficulty are creative and keep the game new. However, all aspects of the game maintain a pine-fresh scent.

Initially, Bastion's quick-paced, action-based gameplay is good, simple fun. Truly, without activating an idol or two, the game is a bit on the easy side. Though, should you falter, you're granted one reprieve. An additional pratfall results in running the entire level over again. Normally, a lack of checkpoints in extensive stages is a critical game design flaw, but with adjustable difficulty, this is more than fair. For those looking for a challenge and adrenaline rush, the penalty of running some of the longer levels over again can be enticing; however, those who enjoy whimsical hack-n-slashery need just avoid the idols. Although the game gets harder over time even in its vanilla state, leveling up and weapon upgrades maintain one's interest.

When leveling up and choosing a potion to make The Kid stronger, players have several choices to make. Do I want more mobility when holding up my shield, or do I want to have a slight increase to critical chance? Another shop allows players to purchase gods for the Shrine, potions for leveling up perks, and even special powers for the Arsenal. Other buildings include achievements and weapon upgrading with customization.

Although Bastion egregiously offers pseudo-choices the way so many other games of its ilk do, the customization, challenges, and achievements are well thought out. Valve and Kongregate will tell you with firsthand experience that easy, medium, and hard difficulty achievements are necessary if goal-setting is going to motivate players even a bit; Bastion has this covered. I completed certain auxiliary objectives without even knowing about them, while others took conscious effort and practice.

Thankfully, customization makes challenges easier. In this way, some of the side missions can be thought of more as puzzles with an element of skill, but others will require finesse, alacrity, and accuracy to conquer. However, I didn't find any Excalibur equivalents, and even if I thought I did, my brother glanced over at my screen and asked me how the heck I was using that weapon combination and special power; the sentiments were reciprocated. And isn't this the goal of any designer who includes gameplay options?

As alluded to in the beginning of the review, Bastion is more than just gameplay and a novel plot: it's an experience. For those who've read my King's Bounty reviews, you're probably well-aware of my love of color. Modern gaming can be so monochrome and drab that when a game as vibrant as Bastion comes along, the appeal is two-fold; not only is color in itself enticing, but we're so starved for it that our love for it is accentuated. Additionally, not only has Bastion been graced by daubs of the palette, it's extremely busy. While clutter can certainly reach a threshold, Bastion never oversteps its bounds. The developers made sure to keep the minds and eyes of its consumers occupied while not getting in their way. Another marvel of the layout is just how intuitive foreground breakables are. Many other games leave questions as to what can be examined and destroyed, and what is meant to be left alone in the background. Some may complain that foreground pillars and structures can get in the way, but this reviewer perceives that as a necessary evil given how beautiful the game is.

But what would a game be without music to match the visuals? Although most of the music is forgettable, some of the tunes have lasting power. Keeping with the atmosphere of a western, the occasional acoustic guitar and harmonica make for some innovative RPG music. However, the aural highlights of Bastion lie in its vocal numbers. Simple instrumentation matched with truly melodious voices grants us serene, wistful songs. Couple this with intelligent lyrics, and Bastion leaves an imprint on anyone with a love of music or beating heart.

Typically, voice acting hurts or helps in a humble way. To my knowledge, never has a game been recommended purely because of the voice acting, but Bastion might be the first. Sure, we play games to enjoy deep, fun gameplay and funny or immersive storytelling. However, what if the defining feature was its narrator, and how that story was told? Take away Bastion's voice, and that leaves a pretty good game with fun combat in a slightly unique take on a post-apocalyptic world. With the voice, Bastion isn't just a great game, it's a work of art. Never before had I anticipated a person's name in the credits of a game, just so I could seek them out online and see what they've done and what they will do. I would be absolutely astonished and floored if this is the last we hear of Logan Cunningham.

Finally, the controls are what you would expect of a game of this caliber. Nigh-perfect in its intuitive rolling and hit detection, the only complaints I can make are in its auto-targeting mechanism. Due to Bastion's archaic take on defending, players may steer clear of the shield due to its unreliability. When defending, The Kid automatically faces the nearest target, which makes sense.

When I close a good, long book, I always feel a little sad, as if I had just said good bye to an old friend. I want to know what happens to the characters that I grew to love, but I have to accept the end and move on. Bastion is a short game, which will run most people around five or six hours. Nevertheless, I feel that same kind of loss. Although I truly believe that Bastion could have doubled its length in terms of gameplay, I'm glad that the story didn't risk imploding on itself. Don't let anyone tell you this is a Diablo clone–that would cheapen Bastion; it needs to be heard to be believed.

THIS GAME.

THIS GAME. I'd give it a 9/10 - it's not that there's anything MISSING, per se, but I like to leave a single point open on serious reviews unless I feel the game is inspired by God himself. As it is, 9/10 is pretty much a perfect score. One that I think I've only ever given to Alan Wake and Black Ops 2 Multiplayer. xD

reviewText:
This is not a bad game. But I've owned it for over 2 years and have tried picking it up on several different occasions only to never completely get into it. I don't feel very attached to the characters and story. It's all extremely vague, which can make some games fun because you get curious and want to explore more and play more. But if it wasn't for the narrator talking into my ear there would be no story. His voice is everything... and I kind of don't like that.

The gameplay felt really tight. The weapons can be somewhat interesting when you combine them with different power ups. I probably should have set my game on a harder difficulty because I found no challenge to it, but that's my own fault. I used the keyboard. The artwork is swell. I never fell in love with the music, although it is ever-present and perfectly fitting. The enemies are cool but kind of repetitive. I think that's about it. There's really nothing that stands out wrong with the game in my opinion, except for the story resting so highly on one overdramatic voice, even though that's the part everyone raves about. And to me, if you have a problem with the story then you have a problem with the game because the story is one of the biggest reasons why I'd ever even play a single-player game.

I believe that I now realize what my other main issue is. I said there's really nothing wrong with the game"
date: but there's also nothing that special about it either. You strip away the artwork and the [annoying] narrator and it's just some run-of-the-mill barebones top down "twin-stick shooter"
recommended: as someone in my comments had said. Twin-stick shooter. That genre might still be fresh enough for many people but for someone like me gaming into their late 20's who has already played quite a bit of those it doesn't do enough for me. Bastion is just not for me I suppose."

reviewText:
Bastion is by far one of the greatest games that I've played. Although the game is linear, it's easy to forget that as you slowly uncover the details of what caused the Calamity. In addition, there is a large amount of customizability with what weapons you use, and they allow for many different playstyles. In addition, instead of picking an arbitrary difficulty at the beginning (For example, if you pick between easy and hard, what makes hard more difficult than easy?), the game allows you to create your own challenge - while also rewarding you with more EXP if you choose to do so. The storytelling in the game is also phenomenal, and makes replaying the game so much more fun - because you can't catch every detail in your first play through. I've beaten the game many times and still notice something new each time.

Overall, this is a great game and shows that Supergiant Games will definitely continue to be a great video game company.

reviewText:
It's an isometric action indie game (although I don't know how being published by Warner Bros is indie but nevermind that.) This is probably the first indie non-sandbox game I’ve played.

It follows through the adventures of a boy the „Kid” who’s entire race was wiped off of the face of the earth „Bastion” by a strange event called the „Calamity”. The „Kid” is trying to salvage through the remains of his civilization exploring the world trying to find clues, and certain items to restore „Bastion” to its former glory.

I’ll follow the usual format of game reviews just to make it easier to read.

-	Story/Quests

The story itself is quite mediocre I’d say, there are no mind-blowing twists or hilarious moments in it. The quest mechanic are basically the same „go and fetch this and that” repeating around 16 times which can be tedious after a while. However an unique feature of the game is that EVERYTHING is narrated, no not by Morgan Freeman but by a more „macho” sounding gentleman Logan Cunningham who is also great in what he does.
The narration gives an interesting vibe to the game, you feel like you’re part of the story and it feels like „living in the book”, making the fights/progression and story more immersive. The narrator also has some quirky comments when you change your loadout or accidentally fall off of a floating island which made me smile quite a few times.

-	Graphics/Looks

The art of the game is beautiful. Every level has a different story, feel to it which makes you forgive the (otherwise tedious) quests. Everything is colorful, rich and vibrant. Thankfully the game doesn’t have any serious system requirements it runs easily on a laptop so you can enjoy it in its full glory. There’s not much more to say, go watch some trailers or gameplay videos :)

-	Combat/Gameplay

The game is very combat-centric, you don’t have much time to immerse yourself into the game or admire the scenery without getting ♥♥♥♥♥ by the various enemies. It’s like Bioshock Infinite, beautiful and interesting but you must keep on grinding through hordes of various enemies. The enemy variety is alright when you start to get bored there’s always a new type of enemy appearing. The combat itself is surprisingly fun with a great variety in weapons and combat styles. There is no quick-save or even checkpoints, a game is only saved after you successfully finish a level.

You have one primary and a secondary weapon slot and a variety of weapons (ranging from katanas to muskets) which you can upgrade. You also have a special ability slot which you can use to throw grenades or place a decoy of yourself to confuse enemies. There’s supposed to be an alchemy system and stealth in the game but I didn’t really want to get into it, I stick to my guns thanks. The combat is incredibly fast-paced and hectic with tons of enemies coming at you, sometimes you even feel like you’re playing an isometric „Shoot ’em Up” dodging projectiles all the time. The game is HARD, the enemies hit hard even on easy difficulty you find yourself grasping for breath, looking for health potions and trying to survive. You have three chances to „respawn” after dying if you exceed it then you must start the level all over again. There are the usual boss batles and you should apply a different strategy for different foes.

Conclusion:

Bastion is a fun little game, but it has its flaws. I love reading classic literature in my free time so my expectations of a „story” are quite high when I play video games. The game is beautiful, the combat is fun but challenging, and the narration brings a refreshing change to the storytelling. I recommend it to people who like games with an unique world, and lore but who also like getting their hands dirty in frequent fights. I don’t recommend it to people who don’t like hard fast paced, crazy combat and to people who don’t like to start a level all over again. The game takes around 6-8 hours to beat, but I heard that there are two different endings so it gives some replay value (I didn't really care about the story so one playthrough was enough for me :) )

Story 6/10
Graphics 9/10
Combat 8/10
Overall 8/10

Oh I forgot to mention:

THE SOUNDTRACK IS F*****ING AMAZING!!!!

reviewText:
What do you say to someone who’s played it all?

“Buy this game. Please.”

Bastion is one of the “big names” of the Indie scene. Although its reach has gone farther than most games made by small companies thanks to a partnership between Supergiant Games and Warner Brothers, Bastion still has the charm that only a small-time game can. From the graphics to the gameplay, the music to the narration, you know you’ve found something special from the moment the game begins.
The game follows the story of a boy known only as “the Kid” following a catastrophic event called the Calamity. With the world falling to pieces, it’s up to the Kid to collect cores to rebuild the bastion and restore life. An old man known as Rucks narrates the story as it plays out. Along the way, the Kid must fight off monsters, enemies, and even nature itself to retrieve the cores and save the bastion, with a few surprises along the way.
Artistically, Bastion is a gem. Jen Zee’s artwork gives the world an organic, colorful feeling that constantly evolves around the player’s actions. The soundtrack, composed by Darren Korb, is as beautiful as it is fitting for the game’s story. With a very down-to-earth feel and haunting lyrics on a number of tracks, the soundtrack makes for good listening both in and out of the game. Better yet, it’s also available for purchase on the Steam marketplace.
In respects to gameplay, Bastion is a generally easy game. I had little difficulty making my way through on my first play-through, and never encountered a game over. That being said, the “Shrine” portion of the game allows players to raise the difficulty in exchange for more fragments (currency used for upgrades and purchases) and XP. With that in mind, the game can be made as easy or as difficult as the player would like, with the best benefits reserved for those who play the hardest.
What Bastion is known for most of all is its narrator, Rucks, who narrates the game’s events as they play out. The old, weathered voice of the man gives a dimension to the game that few others can hold a flame to. His voice guides players through the plot at several key points, but is also free-flowing at other instances. Rucks might comment on the weapons the Kid uses, offer hints when needed, and even comment on little things such as falling off the stage. The story is framed as Zucks telling the story--to whom? That comes in time.
Bastion is a gem, and for good reasons. Its fascinating story is told through every medium--art, music, and plot--and culminates in one fantastic experience. If you have the opportunity to experience Bastion, do so.

reviewText:
Bastion is a fine action-adventure game set in a fantastic world after a near apocalyptic event. The scenery is superb, beautiful places that show some of this world's former glory. The gameplay is quite varied, as there is a wide variety of weapons, each with their respective upgrades and secret skills, that you can combine in every way you want. You can also customize the difficulty by invoking different gods that will make foes stronger in a variety of ways, while providing you with greater rewards.

The soundtrack is another strong point for this game. Each song seems fitting to the situation you're currently in, and there's plenty of them.

Finally, the story is very well crafted. The narration aspect is quite interesting, and as you progress, it begins to make more and more sense. Not to mention that a second playthrough, in New Game+, will add new details.

All in all, a highly recommendable game.

reviewText:
Finished it in 6,5 hours. Well worth the money, even though I think it's a bit short in the end (storywise). The graphics are outstanding by the way. They reminded me of Braid.

The game itself plays like a linear action RPG. During your quest you'll receive lots of weapons, that you can upgrade several times. There are also idols to increase the difficulty, a distillery to equip potions with different effects and challenge rooms to earn extra items. There really is a lot to do in this game (never mind the story for now) so it could take you about 12-13 hours, maybe even longer, to 100% this game.

To be short: this game should be in your collection, no matter what.

[Rating: 88/100]

reviewText:
What do you say to someone who’s played it all?

“Buy this game. Please.”

Bastion is one of the “big names” of the Indie scene. Although its reach has gone farther than most games made by small companies thanks to a partnership between Supergiant Games and Warner Brothers, Bastion still has the charm that only a small-time game can. From the graphics to the gameplay, the music to the narration, you know you’ve found something special from the moment the game begins.
The game follows the story of a boy known only as “the Kid” following a catastrophic event called the Calamity. With the world falling to pieces, it’s up to the Kid to collect cores to rebuild the bastion and restore life. An old man known as Rucks narrates the story as it plays out. Along the way, the Kid must fight off monsters, enemies, and even nature itself to retrieve the cores and save the bastion, with a few surprises along the way.
Artistically, Bastion is a gem. Jen Zee’s artwork gives the world an organic, colorful feeling that constantly evolves around the player’s actions. The soundtrack, composed by Darren Korb, is as beautiful as it is fitting for the game’s story. With a very down-to-earth feel and haunting lyrics on a number of tracks, the soundtrack makes for good listening both in and out of the game. Better yet, it’s also available for purchase on the Steam marketplace.
In respects to gameplay, Bastion is a generally easy game. I had little difficulty making my way through on my first play-through, and never encountered a game over. That being said, the “Shrine” portion of the game allows players to raise the difficulty in exchange for more fragments (currency used for upgrades and purchases) and XP. With that in mind, the game can be made as easy or as difficult as the player would like, with the best benefits reserved for those who play the hardest.
What Bastion is known for most of all is its narrator, Rucks, who narrates the game’s events as they play out. The old, weathered voice of the man gives a dimension to the game that few others can hold a flame to. His voice guides players through the plot at several key points, but is also free-flowing at other instances. Rucks might comment on the weapons the Kid uses, offer hints when needed, and even comment on little things such as falling off the stage. The story is framed as Zucks telling the story--to whom? That comes in time.
Bastion is a gem, and for good reasons. Its fascinating story is told through every medium--art, music, and plot--and culminates in one fantastic experience. If you have the opportunity to experience Bastion, do so.

reviewText:
I recently reviewed this game for my game review blog, Five Penny Review. If you enjoy this review, please visit my page:
http://fivepennyreview.blogspot.com/2013/04/bastion.html

What sets this game apart?
Conceptually, Bastion could be considered a fairly typical action RPG.  It features a silent protagonist, a small cast of enemies, a selection of weapons for which you develop new skills as you progress, and a combat system heavy on combos and dodge rolling.  What makes it unique is its presentation, and to say that Bastion is an artistic endeavor would be an understatement.  The art creates a world somewhere between catastrophe and storybook, the music has a multicultural feel that creates something familiar but foreign.  The only character to speak is the narrator, who is a constant presence in the game and provides information about the world, the characters, and your course of action, serving as both storyteller and tutorial.  The way this was accomplished creates an experience that envelops you in what would otherwise be a decent game.

What is the difficulty factor?
The tutorials for Bastion are pretty straight forward, and the controls are fairly simple to pick up and play.  The narrator also does a good job providing little hints for moving forward, especially early in the game.  The timing for dodge rolling, blocking with your shield, and even just attacking can take some time to master and feel a bit clumsy, especially given the differences in the available weapons.  The weapon proving grounds provide a good method for mastering the techniques for various weapons.

As far as the challenge curve goes, Bastion does a great job of starting off easy and escalating slowly to a proper difficulty.  The proving grounds and dream sequences allow you to build up your level and money, often while earning new techniques.  If you aren’t feeling challenged, the shrine allows you to drastically increase the difficulty of specific aspects of the game to increase your rewards, allowing you to customize the difficulty of the game in a unique way.

Does it use media effectively?
Bastion has a very stylized appearance that gives it a persistent otherworldly feeling, like you are experiencing a dream or watching the illustrations of a story book.  The enemies and foreground objects are often strange and brightly colored, the world itself is made up of chunks of ground floating in mid-air that form as you progress, and the backgrounds consist of little more than gradient colors and clouds.  The culmination of this look is a sense of nihilistic beauty, which seems appropriate in drawing the audience in to the story of the survivors of a world shattering apocalypse.

The music in Bastion is a bit hard to describe, both because of its occasional strangeness and the obvious scope of its influences.  At its core there is often a folksy acoustic guitar, but many of the tracks feature distinctly eastern sounds as well.  The lyrics are simple and poignant, and the vocal tracks have a haunting beauty to them.  Ultimately, the music has the same effect as the visuals, to draw you in to a place that is both alien and beautiful, and reminding you of what has been lost to the world you explore.

Best moment in the game?
While not a specific moment, the best thing about this game to me was Rucks, the narrator.  Voice actor Logan Cunningham did a great job creating a character that sounded familiar and warm, further connecting you to what could otherwise be a somewhat alien world.  Rucks serves as a storyteller and historian for the viewer as the game progresses, serving as the medium for each major plot point in the game, and telling you about the history of places, events, and character as they become relevant to the story.  In addition, he provides commentary as you move through each level.  There is something shocking about the first time you hear Rucks provide commentary on what is happening in the course of a battle, something that seems like it could not be scripted, but obviously must be.

Who needs to play this game?
Once again, I would encourage all brands of gamer to check out this game.  Bastion uses great art, music, and storytelling to create an environment that you can be drawn into.  The action may not always be on par with some modern titles and parts of the game may not feel especially challenging, but the gameplay is always fun and the sliding difficulty scale will help keep you under pressure.  Bastion is available to purchase and download on the X-Box Live Arcade and on Steam.

reviewText:
This review is brought to you by the wonderful Ponxha.

Bastion is indeed one of the most captivating games I've played, gameplay-wise and story-wise.
The art, the soundtrack, the narration. All of those elements made this game.

Gameplay
Bastion has lots of play styles to experiment with. The variety of melee weapons and ranged weapons gives you lots of different combinations to eliminate your foes. Speaking of enemies, each enemy has different ways to eliminate them and as you progress, you'll need the right tricks to cleverly eliminate your foes with the weapons you choose.

Story
I'm not gonna spoil the plot for you, but I can tell you it is one the most heart-warming and clever video game story I've ever experienced. And Logan Cunningham delivers a very fine narration to top it off

Soundtrack
The music in this game really immerses you into the theme of the game. Some parts of the story has successfuly shed a tear because of the beautiful music.

Verdict
+ Extreme variety of weapon play styles
+ Beautiful and captivating art
+ Surreal music
+ Clever and well thought story

10/10

reviewText:
Is your world falling apart? Bastion can relate.

Maybe not in the mental state but taking place in a world that begins to crumble into pieces, Bastion manages to capture a beautiful unique scenery that has a quite amuzing arcade like gameplay.

Positive

The story follows to be short but powerful, the game follows a young boy on the curiosity and discovery on what's happening to his world, and how can you stop it.

Captivating dialouge, you will enjoy this classical hit if you love the enrichment of emotions this story can and does indeed bring.

If you have enough money for the soundtrack i also highly reccomend you download that too. I'm not much on soundtracks, however Bastion does have an extremely rich and cultivating music producer. However the beauty if music is there is aways gonna be a song out there to enjoy....just not for everybody. Thus,

https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLA6BDC6AA59483A76

I give you a quick link to hear some of the music so you can see for yourself if you would rather buy the game with or without it's soundtrack. Im kinda repeating mysef here but again, im not much of a fan for the soundtracks, thats why i recommend this one, because i just absolutely love it.
(I'm listening to the ending credits song as i write this review!!!)

Con

The game doesn't have much of a replaybility, I mean Bastion contains extra modes after the intial completion of the game isn't the type of game you can have 500 hours on....unless you enjoy the game that much but in hinde sight, it is a short game.

Additional Info

The game contains multiple endings. Basion contains about as many choices as the size of one grain of rice, but very powerful in game choices you, the player, have to make.

It is not a choice making game like Mass Effect, but I just needed to add that because I still to this day regret all the decisions this game forced me to make. It's a balance of depression and joy that the presence of the choices were involved.

In short, for any fan of an enticing, rich storyline with captivating scenery and ear endulging music, this game is a must have. Bastion is a definatly an 11/10 in my book and the music is a must have in your itunes library.

reviewText:
Wow. Where should I start? Well, this game is probably my new all-time favorite. It has secured a place in my heart and I look forward to playing other games from Supergiant Games in the near future.
This game has an absolutely beautiful story that engulfs the player in the environment in such a way that I have never before experienced. The set-up for the narration is incredible and makes you feel like you are sitting on the Bastion listening to Rucks tell the story of the Kid.
The music is amazing and captures the environment of the game in a way that I've only seen two other games do before in my life (MGS4, and Borderlands). I will admit, I am a bit biased on the music because I love indie music in general and I love a very acoustic sound, so this was already appealing, but then as the game progresses the music takes a diverse turn that is very rare in any mainstream media. Darren Korb's instrumentation is great and includes a wide variety of instruments, and the vocals are absolutely beautiful (Ashley Barrett, I'm looking at you!).
The art is breathtaking to say the least. The game almost looks like the player is playing in a stained glass mosaic piece and the animation is smooth and natural feeling. The modeling is also superb and does not at all feel clunky.
Lastly, the gameplay is just 100% phenomenal. As mentioned above, the game plays very smoothly and everything feels very natural. The difficulty is at a very good level, giving the player the option to invoke the gods" which provides a more difficult challenge
date: and gives the player more "fragments" and experience to build their character. Bastion's wide variety of customization options makes the game perfectly tailored to the player and ensures that people of all ages and skill levels can enjoy it.\nDo I recommend this game? Absolutely. And not just to people who like Action Role-Playing games

reviewText:
Honestly one of the best games I've ever played.

The artwork is gorgeous, the soundtrack stunning (and one of my favourites of all time) and the storyline is, whilst not necessarily ground-breakingly original, re-inforced through characters who stray from the flat, one dimensional NPCs we're used to.

Everything in this game is beautifully balanced: the Kid's silence is offset by the Narrator's frequent and colourful dialogue, the visuals do not detract from a core mechanic that works well and the characters themselves balance one another.

One of the best features is that the game does offer a dynamic core mechanic: the difficulty can be stepped up through activating Idols, and the variety of weapons and skills allow for a challenging experience...should you desire it!

Overall: a masterfully made game!

And, lest we forget: Logan Cunningham...the gaming world's answer to Morgan Freeman!
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Bastion is a fine action-adventure game set in a fantastic world after a near apocalyptic event. The scenery is superb, beautiful places that show some of this world's former glory. The gameplay is quite varied, as there is a wide variety of weapons, each with their respective upgrades and secret skills, that you can combine in every way you want. You can also customize the difficulty by invoking different gods that will make foes stronger in a variety of ways, while providing you with greater rewards.

The soundtrack is another strong point for this game. Each song seems fitting to the situation you're currently in, and there's plenty of them.

Finally, the story is very well crafted. The narration aspect is quite interesting, and as you progress, it begins to make more and more sense. Not to mention that a second playthrough, in New Game+, will add new details.

All in all, a highly recommendable game.

reviewText:
There's not much to say about Bastion...

Amazing art direction, slick presentation, superb narration, and the soundtrack blends in perfectly with the gameplay. The game mechanics are excellent as well. Every weapons have a unique feeling to them and are fun to use, from light and heavy melee weapons, to bows and guns. Furthermore, weapons' abilities can be customized through a kind of crafting system which allows for different kind of play style with the same weapon. You can also increase the difficulty at any time by selecting up to 10 idols which grant unique boosts to your enemies, but earn you more experience points in return.

Overall, the game's quite short and not very challenging, but that is only because they chose quality over quantity. A highly recommended game and experience.

reviewText:
Proper review supposed to start at the beginning... Ain't so simple with this one

Get Bastion. Really. A discount means it's a steal for you

I'm just fooling

Bastion is an adventure beat-em-up game with unique artstyle, superb storytelling, hypnotizing music, and a meta-ish thingy in the plotline.
Bastion graphical representation used a lot of handpainted scenery, resulting in a beautiful and easy-in-the-eye kind of graphics, you won't find many game that uses this kind (well, aside from other game from Supergiant, Transistor). It'll be a different 'graphics' experience for you with Bastion

The story in this game are told with a narrator as the player progresses through the Bastion world. The character player control is silent (and looks like the main character communicate with other using handwriting, as hinted by all the dialogue choices when interacting with others), and all element about Bastion are told by the narrator. The narrator did a really excellent job at delivering the world of Bastion to the player. His voice feels friendly, like someone you've known for so long, yet only meet again after a long separation. You won't feel tired listening to the narrator thoughout the game, and it is also a good thing because the way of the storytelling is unique, leaving you with a feeling of wanting to be told more.

Music at the bastion is a little different with other games that usually use orchestra of violin, drum, piano or everything else. It sound like 1 or 2 instrument that playing along with a storyteller, and perfectly captures the predicament of the story being told. This fits a lot with the storytelling style of Bastion.

Not much of gameplay selling point can be told here. Some people might feels the combat is repetitive, and old as there's no differentiation to other game with same type of combat. That might be true, but I find Bastion combat is at good value. The many Arsenal you'll find coupled with passive boost from Distillery and difficulty tweaker from the Shrine will kinda force you to seek new way to combat the enemy and it's good enough for me.

The meta things of Bastion plot is *SPOILER AHEAD  you're supposed to choose a peculiar ending in order for your first playthrough to match with the new game +, the Restoration Protocol. Because the narrator will have some kind of deja vu telling throughout the whole new game + narration, it fits the ending. Also it can be interpreted that as the player, you are the Kid's will that never forget even after time reset itself, the Kid at first want to restore the world before the Calamity happen, but as the player see that restoring the world doesn't prevent the Calamity, on the second playthrough, you know that the correct choice is Evacuation Protocol, thus setting sail for a new home is kinda the right /good ending of Bastion. Bastion is game where a second playthrough is needed to close a loophole that might be caused by 1 ending. And it's spectacular for a game this small to have this kind of meta story.
The whole narration or the story is actually Ruck telling the story to Zia about how they all come together, while waiting for the Kid to return from the Tazal Terminal at the last level, so you are playing a memory of Ruck, and the only real time moment Ruck's narrating is when we save/leave Zulf and afterward.
Also, dramatic moment when you decide to rescue Zulf. The music is plain tearjerker, the tension of the situation feels heroic and out of respect, you'll struck in awe playing that part.

It's finished...
No matter what you decide to buy Bastion or not, you done good...
The Bastion's gonna take us to a better gametime
So long kid, Maybe I'll see you in the next one
*cue Setting Sail, Coming Home music (youtube it!)
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
The Good
The main reason to play this game is for the story, most particularly the interesting way that story is presented.  Everything is narrated, and the narration serves both to guide the player through various parts of the game, it's also informed and appropriately altered by the player's actions.

The gameplay is very solid in most aspects, and works very well in its isometric framework.  The graphics are excellent, and it's endlessly fascinating to watch the stages gradually take form as you move around, and just as fascinating to run around destroying as much of it as you can.  The real star of the background is the music, however, which is just chock full of beautiful and catchy sounds.  Shelling out $9.99 for the soundtrack is a bargain as far as I'm concerned.

The Bad
The mechanics of the game have surprisingly little variation given how many different weapons, abilities, and the like that are available.  Many of the enemies can be taken out in a lot different ways, meaning there's very little reason to bother switching away from whatever weapon you've picked as your favorite since odds are it'll still do the trick.  I do like the combat, but I also think it could have benefited a great deal from just a little more depth.

Overall
A very fun game with a damn fine soundtrack and a good, thought-provoking story presented in a unique way.  I would definitely recommend giving it a try, and I personally look forward to seeing and playing SuperGiant Games' future endeavors.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
To me, a gaming masterpeice is a game which can entertain any sort of gamer. Bastion could be titled a gaming masterpeice, much like Dust: An Elysian Tail. It's gameplay core and mechanics are solid, and is good enough to keep you nice and entertained for a couple hours in one session, and the gold narration and storytelling is only there to refine and back it up. These two combined can result to some pretty damn nice immersion, which is a thing some games fail at doing, and some succeed at. Bastion succeeded and went over the charts.

The only things I don't like about the game are very small nitpicks, like not being able to replay levels the player enjoyed, but that also gives the game a good sense of progression, to counter that nitpick.

If you're a fan of both good, addictive beat-em-up gameplay and storytelling bundled into a nice package, then Bastion is for you. I was put off by the fact it was 2D at first glance, but the game itself completely turned my stereotypes upside down, and that's a damn achivement in it's own right.

reviewText:
This is not just a game, it's a work of art.

Through the whole game you'll be led by the amazing narrator Logan Cunningham. It feels more like you're reading a mystical and cozy story than playing a hack and slash video game.

If you're looking for a refreshing and beautifully inspiring game, look no further.

reviewText: An amazing game with an original storyline and beautiful soundtrack, Bastion is by far one of the most unique games any one person can play. The concept of an interactive storyline takes on a whole new meaning because of this game and I have yet to witness any other game emulate the power and originality this game exhibits on so many levels. Combining profound concepts with great music, artistic graphics, and a sort of post-apocalyptic scene of its own, Bastion is less of a game and more of a story that you play to hear. For those of you seeking to play the best, most interesting, and original games out there, I cannot recommend Bastion enough. You will not be disappointed.

reviewText:
Super nice game. I was bored one day and saw it in my inventory, launched it - and was not bored anymore. Once you finished the game you can replay the story while keeping all unlocked weapons and skills. It's also one of the few games I was looking forward to replay.

The game begins really easy but becomes more and more difficult. If you still feel like the game was too easy to beat you can try out the challenge missions and give the enemies perks that make them far more dangerous.

I really recommend everyone to give this game a try. Now with the Summer Sale coming it should be 75% off again.

reviewText:
Finished it in 6,5 hours. Well worth the money, even though I think it's a bit short in the end (storywise). The graphics are outstanding by the way. They reminded me of Braid.

The game itself plays like a linear action RPG. During your quest you'll receive lots of weapons, that you can upgrade several times. There are also idols to increase the difficulty, a distillery to equip potions with different effects and challenge rooms to earn extra items. There really is a lot to do in this game (never mind the story for now) so it could take you about 12-13 hours, maybe even longer, to 100% this game.

To be short: this game should be in your collection, no matter what.

[Rating: 88/100]

reviewText:
Bastion is a fine action-adventure game set in a fantastic world after a near apocalyptic event. The scenery is superb, beautiful places that show some of this world's former glory. The gameplay is quite varied, as there is a wide variety of weapons, each with their respective upgrades and secret skills, that you can combine in every way you want. You can also customize the difficulty by invoking different gods that will make foes stronger in a variety of ways, while providing you with greater rewards.

The soundtrack is another strong point for this game. Each song seems fitting to the situation you're currently in, and there's plenty of them.

Finally, the story is very well crafted. The narration aspect is quite interesting, and as you progress, it begins to make more and more sense. Not to mention that a second playthrough, in New Game+, will add new details.

All in all, a highly recommendable game.

reviewText:
Is your world falling apart? Bastion can relate.

Maybe not in the mental state but taking place in a world that begins to crumble into pieces, Bastion manages to capture a beautiful unique scenery that has a quite amuzing arcade like gameplay.

Positive

The story follows to be short but powerful, the game follows a young boy on the curiosity and discovery on what's happening to his world, and how can you stop it.

Captivating dialouge, you will enjoy this classical hit if you love the enrichment of emotions this story can and does indeed bring.

If you have enough money for the soundtrack i also highly reccomend you download that too. I'm not much on soundtracks, however Bastion does have an extremely rich and cultivating music producer. However the beauty if music is there is aways gonna be a song out there to enjoy....just not for everybody. Thus,

https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLA6BDC6AA59483A76

I give you a quick link to hear some of the music so you can see for yourself if you would rather buy the game with or without it's soundtrack. Im kinda repeating mysef here but again, im not much of a fan for the soundtracks, thats why i recommend this one, because i just absolutely love it.
(I'm listening to the ending credits song as i write this review!!!)

Con

The game doesn't have much of a replaybility, I mean Bastion contains extra modes after the intial completion of the game isn't the type of game you can have 500 hours on....unless you enjoy the game that much but in hinde sight, it is a short game.

Additional Info

The game contains multiple endings. Basion contains about as many choices as the size of one grain of rice, but very powerful in game choices you, the player, have to make.

It is not a choice making game like Mass Effect, but I just needed to add that because I still to this day regret all the decisions this game forced me to make. It's a balance of depression and joy that the presence of the choices were involved.

In short, for any fan of an enticing, rich storyline with captivating scenery and ear endulging music, this game is a must have. Bastion is a definatly an 11/10 in my book and the music is a must have in your itunes library.

reviewText:
Wow. Where should I start? Well, this game is probably my new all-time favorite. It has secured a place in my heart and I look forward to playing other games from Supergiant Games in the near future.
This game has an absolutely beautiful story that engulfs the player in the environment in such a way that I have never before experienced. The set-up for the narration is incredible and makes you feel like you are sitting on the Bastion listening to Rucks tell the story of the Kid.
The music is amazing and captures the environment of the game in a way that I've only seen two other games do before in my life (MGS4, and Borderlands). I will admit, I am a bit biased on the music because I love indie music in general and I love a very acoustic sound, so this was already appealing, but then as the game progresses the music takes a diverse turn that is very rare in any mainstream media. Darren Korb's instrumentation is great and includes a wide variety of instruments, and the vocals are absolutely beautiful (Ashley Barrett, I'm looking at you!).
The art is breathtaking to say the least. The game almost looks like the player is playing in a stained glass mosaic piece and the animation is smooth and natural feeling. The modeling is also superb and does not at all feel clunky.
Lastly, the gameplay is just 100% phenomenal. As mentioned above, the game plays very smoothly and everything feels very natural. The difficulty is at a very good level, giving the player the option to invoke the gods" which provides a more difficult challenge
date: and gives the player more "fragments" and experience to build their character. Bastion's wide variety of customization options makes the game perfectly tailored to the player and ensures that people of all ages and skill levels can enjoy it.\nDo I recommend this game? Absolutely. And not just to people who like Action Role-Playing games
recommended: but to everyone who wants to play a game that is
hoursPlayed: in the most modest of terms
voteText: perfect. Bastion is everything a player could ever want in a game
helpfulPercent: and is a must-have for anybody who has the ability to play it.\n\n"Now The Kid sees somethin' stranger still; his mind races. Did anyone else survive? Sure enough
votesHelpful: he finds another. He finds me." - Rucks

reviewText:
Oh I love this game!!!

It might not be something to get a ton of hours out of or regularly play, but its one of the most original RPGs. It really didn't feel bland at all. The game's simple, but very fun to play. Its good to get into if you don't want to learn a complex system or devote a bunch of time into going through an RPG. Its not a long game, but that doesn't make it lesser. There's some replayability to it with different modes too.

Bastion's strongest point is the story. Oh my God its so good! A bit depressing, but so strong. It had a great impact on me and is easily a game that will never be forgotten.
I won't speak much on it. You have to play through it for yourself.
Also, the story is narrated. Its pretty neat and really sets the mood of the game. I couldn't imagine playing the game without the narration!

The art is gooorgeous. It has a very artsy look and is quite colourful. Its pleasing to look at. I liked it a lot.

The music is also excellent. Has an OST worth playing outside of the game. The style of music was pretty unique. Some really great tracks and its something I still listen to here and there.

There's a few different ways to play the game when it comes to controls. It all runs very well. No issues.

Bastion is just a total masterpiece. If you haven't played it you need to. Its one of those must-play indie titles that people will still be talking about years from now. Kind of the FF7 of indie games :)

reviewText: I just finished this game for the first time. The last stage was a rollercoaster of feelings and morality in the best possible way. But I'm getting ahead of myself...\n\nThe gameplay? Simple enough. You take two weapons and use them to destroy things. Each weapon usually has a couple different things they can do, but you can use any combination of two, plus a secret attack
date:
which is a special move that is either related to one of your weapons or a special attack in itself. You also have access to a shield that can block or reflect attacks, and your character isn't half bad at dodge rolling either.

As for the story? Well, I'm sure everyone's heard of the fantastic narrator. You, as the Kid, are tasked with travelling about a world torn asunder by the Calamity and finding Cores to put into a monument in the middle of the Bastion. And for what? Hell, I'm not gonna tell you. Figure it out yourself, but be warned that the story is pretty damn feels inducing. Lots of tear jerkers, sad and glad alike.

Just remember to keep moving forwards. The past is the past, and you should focus on the future. ^^

reviewText: Why I play games is both for the challenge of the gameplay and the immersion of the story itself. On both counts Bastion is superb. The story itself can be hard to grasp while you're too busy learning the ropes and not trying to die, but this only serves to make replaying it all the more rewarding. You're in a post-apocalyptic world, and all you have is the voice of a Stranger guiding your steps, to build a Bastion where all can be safe, all can be rebuilt, though your enemies won't see it that way. If you take advantage of all the game has to offer, you'll find that your skills have been challenged to the utmost and you are the better for it; and tears may come to your eyes when you make your final choice.

reviewText:
Oh man, where do I start? I absolutely LOVE this game. It is one of my favorite indie games that I've ever played (though I do still have a lot left to get around to!).

The story of Bastion is definitely an interesting one, and the way you learn more of the details is relatively simple but intriguing. For instance, learning through the Dream levels turns out to be more fun than you would expect. The perspective of the characters shifts as the game goes on and it definitely has you wonder what is going on.

I liked the frame of everything with the narration, but I don't want to spoil any of the story so I won't say any more. The graphics of the game are great; it is straight up beautiful to look at. Very nice sound all around, and I love the music it has. The actual vocal songs they created were amazing as well and fit the style of their scenes almost perfectly.

Gameplay-wise, Bastion still continues pulling things off. There are enough unique enemies and bosses in the game to keep things interesting, and the weapons available also allow for you to test out different builds. The development of the Bastion is nice, even if you end up building everything in one playthrough (meaning you can't necessarily make a bad" choice of what to build). But it helps tie everything into the world as a whole. Each level has a unique feeling to it and definitely keeps me focused. The training grounds for the weapons give you some nice challenges to overcome
date: and all of them are certainly doable. The potions you can equip further your build for Kid.\n\nAll in all

reviewText:
Four hours into this game and it's definitely worth saying a few things. I'll start with the graphics only because the style in which this world is built is breathtaking. The art direction is watercolours, and do they ever add a fluidity to the movements of The Kid, the silent protagonist of whom you are controlling in this adventure. The colours themselves either have an undeniable shine to them that gently turn into black and white as your health decreases. So does your vision, which I found to be a great mechanic to have.

The story is unique in where a narrator occassionally comments on your actions, while giving the player a sense of direction of where they are going and why. Honestly it's the only sense of direction you are likely to receive, given as to how each level is summoned" step by step.

A final word would be on the soundtrack. It goes with the game perfectly. What else is there to say?

Get yourself this game if you're a fan of Adventure games!"

reviewText:
What do you say to someone who’s played it all?

“Buy this game. Please.”

Bastion is one of the “big names” of the Indie scene. Although its reach has gone farther than most games made by small companies thanks to a partnership between Supergiant Games and Warner Brothers, Bastion still has the charm that only a small-time game can. From the graphics to the gameplay, the music to the narration, you know you’ve found something special from the moment the game begins.
The game follows the story of a boy known only as “the Kid” following a catastrophic event called the Calamity. With the world falling to pieces, it’s up to the Kid to collect cores to rebuild the bastion and restore life. An old man known as Rucks narrates the story as it plays out. Along the way, the Kid must fight off monsters, enemies, and even nature itself to retrieve the cores and save the bastion, with a few surprises along the way.
Artistically, Bastion is a gem. Jen Zee’s artwork gives the world an organic, colorful feeling that constantly evolves around the player’s actions. The soundtrack, composed by Darren Korb, is as beautiful as it is fitting for the game’s story. With a very down-to-earth feel and haunting lyrics on a number of tracks, the soundtrack makes for good listening both in and out of the game. Better yet, it’s also available for purchase on the Steam marketplace.
In respects to gameplay, Bastion is a generally easy game. I had little difficulty making my way through on my first play-through, and never encountered a game over. That being said, the “Shrine” portion of the game allows players to raise the difficulty in exchange for more fragments (currency used for upgrades and purchases) and XP. With that in mind, the game can be made as easy or as difficult as the player would like, with the best benefits reserved for those who play the hardest.
What Bastion is known for most of all is its narrator, Rucks, who narrates the game’s events as they play out. The old, weathered voice of the man gives a dimension to the game that few others can hold a flame to. His voice guides players through the plot at several key points, but is also free-flowing at other instances. Rucks might comment on the weapons the Kid uses, offer hints when needed, and even comment on little things such as falling off the stage. The story is framed as Zucks telling the story--to whom? That comes in time.
Bastion is a gem, and for good reasons. Its fascinating story is told through every medium--art, music, and plot--and culminates in one fantastic experience. If you have the opportunity to experience Bastion, do so.

reviewText:
From the second you drop into the game ~ quite literally ~ you're greeted by a deep, rich voice who decides to narrate your every move from that point on. You travel through numerous regions filled with gorgeous handpainted artwork, finding an arsenal of unique, diverse weapons and learn to master them all through various trials of skill. Finally, as you come closer and closer to the end of the line, you slowly uncover the pieces of a heartbreaking tale between two peoples that leads to the calamity.

4 years later, this game still has high replay value and I constantly listen to the soundtrack outside of the game.

Awesome story. Awesome narration. Awesome music. Awesome gameplay. Awesome game. One of the best games I've ever played.
