reviewText:
I recently reviewed this game for my game review blog, Five Penny Review. If you enjoy this review, please visit my page:
http://fivepennyreview.blogspot.com/2013/04/bastion.html

What sets this game apart?
Conceptually, Bastion could be considered a fairly typical action RPG.  It features a silent protagonist, a small cast of enemies, a selection of weapons for which you develop new skills as you progress, and a combat system heavy on combos and dodge rolling.  What makes it unique is its presentation, and to say that Bastion is an artistic endeavor would be an understatement.  The art creates a world somewhere between catastrophe and storybook, the music has a multicultural feel that creates something familiar but foreign.  The only character to speak is the narrator, who is a constant presence in the game and provides information about the world, the characters, and your course of action, serving as both storyteller and tutorial.  The way this was accomplished creates an experience that envelops you in what would otherwise be a decent game.

What is the difficulty factor?
The tutorials for Bastion are pretty straight forward, and the controls are fairly simple to pick up and play.  The narrator also does a good job providing little hints for moving forward, especially early in the game.  The timing for dodge rolling, blocking with your shield, and even just attacking can take some time to master and feel a bit clumsy, especially given the differences in the available weapons.  The weapon proving grounds provide a good method for mastering the techniques for various weapons.

As far as the challenge curve goes, Bastion does a great job of starting off easy and escalating slowly to a proper difficulty.  The proving grounds and dream sequences allow you to build up your level and money, often while earning new techniques.  If you aren’t feeling challenged, the shrine allows you to drastically increase the difficulty of specific aspects of the game to increase your rewards, allowing you to customize the difficulty of the game in a unique way.

Does it use media effectively?
Bastion has a very stylized appearance that gives it a persistent otherworldly feeling, like you are experiencing a dream or watching the illustrations of a story book.  The enemies and foreground objects are often strange and brightly colored, the world itself is made up of chunks of ground floating in mid-air that form as you progress, and the backgrounds consist of little more than gradient colors and clouds.  The culmination of this look is a sense of nihilistic beauty, which seems appropriate in drawing the audience in to the story of the survivors of a world shattering apocalypse.

The music in Bastion is a bit hard to describe, both because of its occasional strangeness and the obvious scope of its influences.  At its core there is often a folksy acoustic guitar, but many of the tracks feature distinctly eastern sounds as well.  The lyrics are simple and poignant, and the vocal tracks have a haunting beauty to them.  Ultimately, the music has the same effect as the visuals, to draw you in to a place that is both alien and beautiful, and reminding you of what has been lost to the world you explore.

Best moment in the game?
While not a specific moment, the best thing about this game to me was Rucks, the narrator.  Voice actor Logan Cunningham did a great job creating a character that sounded familiar and warm, further connecting you to what could otherwise be a somewhat alien world.  Rucks serves as a storyteller and historian for the viewer as the game progresses, serving as the medium for each major plot point in the game, and telling you about the history of places, events, and character as they become relevant to the story.  In addition, he provides commentary as you move through each level.  There is something shocking about the first time you hear Rucks provide commentary on what is happening in the course of a battle, something that seems like it could not be scripted, but obviously must be.

Who needs to play this game?
Once again, I would encourage all brands of gamer to check out this game.  Bastion uses great art, music, and storytelling to create an environment that you can be drawn into.  The action may not always be on par with some modern titles and parts of the game may not feel especially challenging, but the gameplay is always fun and the sliding difficulty scale will help keep you under pressure.  Bastion is available to purchase and download on the X-Box Live Arcade and on Steam.

reviewText: Bastion combines a wonderful mix of story, art, music, and gameplay all in a way that feels unique to itself.  The game starts you off with little direction but the narrator's voice as you get used to the controls, combat system, level flow, and most importantly the signature level design.  Every environment is Bastion builds" itself from the ground up around you creating a very unique take on the "fog of war" style exploration you commonly see in strategy games.  Story-wise all of this is the result of some far-flung calamity that literally destroyed a good chunk of the world.  This puts the story's focus half on keeping up the progress of the Bastion's buildings and exploration of what's left around you.\n\nThe graphics are wonderfully rendered and everything looks like a mix of semi-realistic 3D and hand-drawn sprites similar to a sort of top-down version of Braid.  Despite the bleak undertones
date: the colors are vibrant even in the darker levels and every place feels both desolate yet full of life as you see what's become of the world around you.  All of these are explored via your home base- the titular Bastion which acts both as a hub for missions
hoursPlayed: weapons
voteText: and side-quests
helpfulPercent: but also serves to both tell and fill in the holes of the story you missed through the narration that goes on throughout the levels.\n\nThere are only four named characters in the game counting the protagonist

All of them have special reactions to pretty much everything you bring back with you on each trip and each has a backstory to explore through special bonus levels.  While interaction with them is minimalistic at best

This game's combat system is tight and responsive and features enough variety to support many playthroughs. There are also a set of challenge levels that I still haven't completed.

Overall recommendation: Buy.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText: A really beautiful game! The soundtrack is gorgeous, the character design is unique, and the scenery is absolutely breathtaking. It's passionate and if you're like me, invokes deep emotion. The story is great, gameplay is fun, and the narrator is awesome. The ending of this game left me with a slightly melancholy feeling but it was the good kind. I won't deny that I definitely teared up more than once in this game. I really enjoyed this game, especially the music and art. And the story. I enjoyed everything, really.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText: I became interested in 'Bastion' when I first saw its beautiful illustrations. The artwork was so stunning that I intended to play the game purely for its art direction. However, within moments of beginning the game, I found myself captivated by the narrator (who tells the story in a 'Shawshank Redemption'-like style) and immersed in the game mechanics. The story of Bastion unfolded steadily and controls were explained so clearly that it was difficult to put this game down.\n\nEasily one of my favourites, I strongly recommend Bastion and prefer it over 'Transistor'.

reviewText:
Proper review supposed to start at the beginning... Ain't so simple with this one

Get Bastion. Really. A discount means it's a steal for you

I'm just fooling

Bastion is an adventure beat-em-up game with unique artstyle, superb storytelling, hypnotizing music, and a meta-ish thingy in the plotline.
Bastion graphical representation used a lot of handpainted scenery, resulting in a beautiful and easy-in-the-eye kind of graphics, you won't find many game that uses this kind (well, aside from other game from Supergiant, Transistor). It'll be a different 'graphics' experience for you with Bastion

The story in this game are told with a narrator as the player progresses through the Bastion world. The character player control is silent (and looks like the main character communicate with other using handwriting, as hinted by all the dialogue choices when interacting with others), and all element about Bastion are told by the narrator. The narrator did a really excellent job at delivering the world of Bastion to the player. His voice feels friendly, like someone you've known for so long, yet only meet again after a long separation. You won't feel tired listening to the narrator thoughout the game, and it is also a good thing because the way of the storytelling is unique, leaving you with a feeling of wanting to be told more.

Music at the bastion is a little different with other games that usually use orchestra of violin, drum, piano or everything else. It sound like 1 or 2 instrument that playing along with a storyteller, and perfectly captures the predicament of the story being told. This fits a lot with the storytelling style of Bastion.

Not much of gameplay selling point can be told here. Some people might feels the combat is repetitive, and old as there's no differentiation to other game with same type of combat. That might be true, but I find Bastion combat is at good value. The many Arsenal you'll find coupled with passive boost from Distillery and difficulty tweaker from the Shrine will kinda force you to seek new way to combat the enemy and it's good enough for me.

The meta things of Bastion plot is *SPOILER AHEAD  you're supposed to choose a peculiar ending in order for your first playthrough to match with the new game +, the Restoration Protocol. Because the narrator will have some kind of deja vu telling throughout the whole new game + narration, it fits the ending. Also it can be interpreted that as the player, you are the Kid's will that never forget even after time reset itself, the Kid at first want to restore the world before the Calamity happen, but as the player see that restoring the world doesn't prevent the Calamity, on the second playthrough, you know that the correct choice is Evacuation Protocol, thus setting sail for a new home is kinda the right /good ending of Bastion. Bastion is game where a second playthrough is needed to close a loophole that might be caused by 1 ending. And it's spectacular for a game this small to have this kind of meta story.
The whole narration or the story is actually Ruck telling the story to Zia about how they all come together, while waiting for the Kid to return from the Tazal Terminal at the last level, so you are playing a memory of Ruck, and the only real time moment Ruck's narrating is when we save/leave Zulf and afterward.
Also, dramatic moment when you decide to rescue Zulf. The music is plain tearjerker, the tension of the situation feels heroic and out of respect, you'll struck in awe playing that part.

It's finished...
No matter what you decide to buy Bastion or not, you done good...
The Bastion's gonna take us to a better gametime
So long kid, Maybe I'll see you in the next one
*cue Setting Sail, Coming Home music (youtube it!)

reviewText:
There's not much to say about Bastion...

Amazing art direction, slick presentation, superb narration, and the soundtrack blends in perfectly with the gameplay. The game mechanics are excellent as well. Every weapons have a unique feeling to them and are fun to use, from light and heavy melee weapons, to bows and guns. Furthermore, weapons' abilities can be customized through a kind of crafting system which allows for different kind of play style with the same weapon. You can also increase the difficulty at any time by selecting up to 10 idols which grant unique boosts to your enemies, but earn you more experience points in return.

Overall, the game's quite short and not very challenging, but that is only because they chose quality over quantity. A highly recommended game and experience.

reviewText:
I've heard so much about this game over the past four years. I was pretty skeptical of all the hype and glowing praise this game has received, but never one to judge unfairly, I picked this up on sale for about $5.

Bastion is good. It is very good. I don't think it's the greatest indie game to have been made, but I can certainly see why people like it so much.

At its heart, Bastion is an isometric hack'n'slash with small elements of dungeon grinding. You have a melee weapon, a ranged weapon, and a special attack. That's it. You can guard and evade roll, but you essentially only have three attacks the whole game. To make this simple formual work you are granted nearly ten different weapons to choose from, all upgradable, and all of which have their own unique special attacks. Further expanding on the simple gameplay is the ability to equip various drinks to give yourself buffs (i.e. extra damage, extra health, etc.)

The game is balanced pretty well. I'm a vet myself, so I didn't have too much of an issue playing through this. There were a few hairy moments here and there, but ultimately Bastion isn't too hard. Unless you want it to be. In which case you can invoke the power of the gods, thus augmenting the enemy builds. While you can make them faster, more agressive, and sturdier, you also get an EXP and money boost for your trouble. Very well balanced.

So the controls are tight, the gameplay is good, so how about the story? I won't give anything away, but it worked. Nothing too crazy, but it held my attention and inspired me to push on. The story itself might be simple, but the biggest draw of the game is the narrator. This was one of the biggest things I heard about this game: the narrator. All I'll say is: play it and find out on your own. It's pretty cool.

While only clocking in at about 6 hours, Bastion manages to give an engrossing and surprisingly deep gameplay experience. Between listening to the narrator and watching the hand drawn world literally fall into place with your every step, Bastion manages to combine tight action gameplay with a unique art driven narrative.

Go buy it.

The story of Bastion unfolded steadily and controls were explained so clearly that it was difficult to put this game down.\n\nEasily one of my favourites, I strongly recommend Bastion and prefer it over 'Transistor'.

reviewText:
Play this Game.

I bought Bastion back when it first showed up on Steam and I played a while but I never got the chance to finish. Recently I was looking for something different to play so I thought I'd fire Bastion up again and give it a play through. I love this game.

Bastion is about a boy who wakes up" in the middle of what the game calls the Calamity. Your story is narrated as you (this boy) progress through levels that build themselves around you. This should not be confused with procedurally generated levels

recommended: tiles form up around you. This is a pretty cool effect even if it's totally linnear.\n\nAs you progress the story deepens

Your weapons and skills are more than strong enough to handle everything the game throws at you. You will have the opportunity to make things harder on yourself as you complete more peices of the Bastion if you wish. Weapons can be upgraded at the Bastion's forge

reviewText: I became interested in 'Bastion' when I first saw its beautiful illustrations. The artwork was so stunning that I intended to play the game purely for its art direction. However, within moments of beginning the game, I found myself captivated by the narrator (who tells the story in a 'Shawshank Redemption'-like style) and immersed in the game mechanics. The story of Bastion unfolded steadily and controls were explained so clearly that it was difficult to put this game down.\n\nEasily one of my favourites, I strongly recommend Bastion and prefer it over 'Transistor'.

reviewText:
Oh man, where do I start? I absolutely LOVE this game. It is one of my favorite indie games that I've ever played (though I do still have a lot left to get around to!).

The story of Bastion is definitely an interesting one, and the way you learn more of the details is relatively simple but intriguing. For instance, learning through the Dream levels turns out to be more fun than you would expect. The perspective of the characters shifts as the game goes on and it definitely has you wonder what is going on.

I liked the frame of everything with the narration, but I don't want to spoil any of the story so I won't say any more. The graphics of the game are great; it is straight up beautiful to look at. Very nice sound all around, and I love the music it has. The actual vocal songs they created were amazing as well and fit the style of their scenes almost perfectly.

Gameplay-wise, Bastion still continues pulling things off. There are enough unique enemies and bosses in the game to keep things interesting, and the weapons available also allow for you to test out different builds. The development of the Bastion is nice, even if you end up building everything in one playthrough (meaning you can't necessarily make a bad" choice of what to build). But it helps tie everything into the world as a whole. Each level has a unique feeling to it and definitely keeps me focused. The training grounds for the weapons give you some nice challenges to overcome
date: and all of them are certainly doable. The potions you can equip further your build for Kid.\n\nAll in all
recommended: Bastion is just an amazing game. It keeps you focused and interested
hoursPlayed: with next to nothing wrong with the game at all. I never got bored with it
voteText: and I never will. I have played it multiple times since it was released
helpfulPercent: and I am always excited to play it every time I return."

reviewText:
I was gifted Bastion by a friend a few years ago. WHY DIDN'T I PLAY IT UNTIL NOW??? IT'S SO MUCH FUN!!!

Wow. I haven't enjoyed a game this much in a long time. The story is great, the visuals are beautiful and colorful. The whole atmosphere is really lovely. The music is so good and it is fluid in that you can flow from one mood to another easily when the narration changes, you enter a specific area on the map, etc.

But what really keeps me coming back is the combat. I don't usually love hack'n'slash, but these weapons & abilities are SO much fun to use. I love all of them, too bad you can only use two at a time. The option of using spirits and idols to make the combat easier/harder depending on different variables you can choose to control is just brilliant. And the eventual upgrades you get, are awesome.

The (increasingly difficult) maps & monsters are all introduced at a good, flowing pace, and in the end are all super fun to fight. I'm probably going to keep playing and toy with the difficulty and different weapon combinations for a while, even after I've beat New Game Plus.

I was very motivated by the narrator and other rewarding, and interesting parts of the game to keep on playing and complete the story. Too often I don't finish games, but the Bastion called my name every hour of the day since I began playing.

Even after you've completed the story there's still more stuff that you can do. Or, rather you can do other fun things while taking your time with the story. It's cool. The currency, and the rate at which it is acquired, is really in sync with natural progression. Everything about this game is just, in sync". It flows. It makes sense. Nothing worried me about it. It is most excellently designed.

Whoever came up with the idea to introduce New Game Plus after you've beat it the first time
date: knew how important that feature would be for people like me who couldn't get enough and wanted to keep playing.\n\nSo
recommended: you should get this game. It's really perfect
hoursPlayed: especially if you like rpg's
voteText: this is a special one. There's really no way you wouldn't enjoy it
helpfulPercent: unless you have real poor coordination and fall off the map all the time (but this is just another fun thing about it).\n\nAlso. Most of the world is destructible so that's fun (it's so pretty though

reviewText:
Apparently I haven't written a review about this game yet. Well, here I go.

The game is fantastic. That's simply it. The story is wonderfully done, and told in an engaging, uninteruptive fashion. The combat system has such a great deal of potential variation, switching up the ability sets and weapons between a good number of choices keeps it constantly interesting. When you beat it the first time through, there's a new game plus which makes the game more challenging, and gives you more toys to play with.

I've played it twice all the way through (~15 hours each) and still listen to the soundtrack on a regular basis. Fully recommended.

reviewText:
After completing Bastion, I realized that the ending is actually really thoughtful, you have two ultimate choices; restore the world to a time before the calamity which is the apocalyptic catastrophe that caused an outbreak in plague, monsters, and fighting factions, or evacuate the Bastion, the mechanical floating island that the old man, Rucks, and you, the kid, live on. That's the central point of the game, to get the Bastion back in working order, gathering shards and minerals to fix the Bastion.

Along the journey, the old man, Rucks, narrates every move you make which might sound annoying but was actually intuitive because of all the context he is able to give. Later on in the game, you figure out that he's narrating to one of the Ura, a girl named Zia who comes to the Bastion after meeting the kid.

I can't say much about the gameplay, as it's rather repetitive, shooting down enemies, blocking, and hacking, no depth to it. But the options you get in weaponry and special abilities and the leveling up make up for it. The game's design is isometric but also 2D, kind of cel shaded. And the floating islands which are part of the world was an interesting way to represent how society has turned out.

Very good game though, with heavy depth in narrative.

9.1/10

reviewText: Bastion is an amazing game, with entertaining gameplay, a unique and beautiful artstyle, and most importantly an intricate, thorough, and moving story. The gameplay and combat is fairly straightforward, but the combinations of two weapons and a single skill can allow for many styles of play, and the lack of straight upgrades adds to this dynamic as well. Additionally, the system of leveling up was unique and further added to the styles of play, and the difficulty of the game scales well, with additional options to offer a greater challenge. Regardless of the engaging gameplay, Bastion excelled in its storytelling. Told through amazing narration, you experience the story of the world of the Bastion. The environment is defined by the artstyle and the soundtrack (which is definitely worth a listen). What stood out most to me concerning the story, however, was its ability to invoke an emotional response from me. As someone who usually plays games for just their gameplay, the whole story (and particularly the conclusion) I was surprised at how much I actually cared about the kid and the characters he meets.\n\nOverall, Bastion is definitely worth a purchase. Decent gameplay in an amazing environment with an engaging story made for a great game.

reviewText:
9.75/10

My freaking god, is this game good? Why are you asking that question? You don't have the time! Play it now!

This would be 10/10 if it wasn't beatable in about 5 hours.

You are The Kid. You awake in a world shaken by the calamity, the name should be enough for you to take a stab at what happened.
But what really shines in this game isn't the amazing narration (which is 10/10) or the gameplay (9.5/10), but the ending.
You have 2 sets of 2 choices, something unheard of until that point.

SPOLIERS: The first decision is to take a half-dead man back home. Answer is simple, yes right? Wrong. For one, you have a leigon of angry people on your doorstep wanting to attack you, and for two... That man is the one who caused this whole mess.
The second one is even harder. Do you revert the world back to before the calamity? Or adventure with the quartet you got to know over the game? If you choose the first option, the calamity will happen again. You will do what happened in the game again. You will choose that choice again, forever. If you choose the next one, you get to adventure with everyone you came to love other the game... The catch? The world stays in it's ruined state, forever.

Get. This. Game.

reviewText:
To Bastion, or not to Bastion, that is the question:
Whether 'tis nobler in the mind to suffer
The slings and arrows of outrageous fortune,
Or to take arms against a sea of troubles
And by opposing end them. To die—to sleep,
No more; and by a sleep to say we end
The heart-ache and the thousand natural shocks
That flesh is heir to: 'tis a consummation
Devoutly to be wish'd. To die, to sleep;
To sleep, perchance to dream—aye, there's the rub:
For in that sleep of death what dreams may come,
When we have shuffled off this mortal coil,
Must give us pause—there's the respect
That makes calamity of so long life.
For who would bear the whips and scorns of time,
Th'oppressor's wrong, the proud man's contumely,
The pangs of dispriz'd love, the law's delay,
The insolence of office, and the spurns
That patient merit of th'unworthy takes,
When he himself might his quietus make
With a bare bodkin? Who would fardels bear,
To grunt and sweat under a weary life,
But that the dread of something after death,
The undiscovere'd country, from whose bourn
No traveller returns, puzzles the will,
And makes us rather bear those ills we have
Than fly to others that we know not of?
Thus conscience does make cowards of us all,
And thus the native hue of resolution
Is sicklied o'er with the pale cast of thought,
And enterprises of great pitch and moment
With this regard their currents turn awry
And lose the name of action.
-Shakespeare

Bastion, a game that resonates so deeply with these timeless lines, puts you in the shoes of the voiceless Kid. The Dreamer, flung into this world torn apart by calamity. Your only companion an heirloom of a long lost love; it’s all you can hold on to as you seek a haven in this hellish -yet beautiful- landscape. All you can do is move forward, and hope.

Proper story's suppose to start at the beginning’. Ain't so simple with this one.”

reviewText:
Bastion is a great example of what happens when a smaller, extremely talented studio really loves their product.  The voice cast and art style/soundtrack are some of the best I've experienced in gaming.  The mechanics also are extremely intuitive and fluid (outside of maybe the rolling but that might just be me. One wouldn't expect to become so attached to a story and characters in a game that started at only 20 USD, but by the end I guarantee you'll be suprisied with how you've fallen in love with them.  I got this game for about 2.00 USD, after playijng it I would gladly have paid full price.

In summary almost every aspect of this game is superb. Do yourself a favor and pick it up, you'll thank me later.

reviewText: Bastion is, hands down, one of the best games I have ever had the fortune of playing. The visuals are incredibly appealing vibrant, fitting colours, detailed artwork. The western-theme nicely by the western music, which is very fitting on the game as a whole. reviewText:
To Bastion, or not to Bastion, that is the question:
Whether 'tis nobler in the mind to suffer
The slings and arrows of outrageous fortune,
Or to take arms against a sea of troubles
And by opposing end them. To die—to sleep,
No more; and by a sleep to say we end
The heart-ache and the thousand natural shocks
That flesh is heir to: 'tis a consummation
Devoutly to be wish'd. To die, to sleep;
To sleep, perchance to dream—aye, there's the rub:
For in that sleep of death what dreams may come,
When we have shuffled off this mortal coil,
Must give us pause—there's the respect
That makes calamity of so long life.
For who would bear the whips and scorns of time,
Th'oppressor's wrong, the proud man's contumely,
The pangs of dispriz'd love, the law's delay,
The insolence of office, and the spurns
That patient merit of th'unworthy takes,
When he himself might his quietus make
With a bare bodkin? Who would fardels bear,
To grunt and sweat under a weary life,
But that the dread of something after death,
The undiscovere'd country, from whose bourn
No traveller returns, puzzles the will,
And makes us rather bear those ills we have
Than fly to others that we know not of?
Thus conscience does make cowards of us all,
And thus the native hue of resolution
Is sicklied o'er with the pale cast of thought,
And enterprises of great pitch and moment
With this regard their currents turn awry
And lose the name of action.
-Shakespeare

Bastion, a game that resonates so deeply with these timeless lines, puts you in the shoes of the voiceless Kid. The Dreamer, flung into this world torn apart by calamity. Your only companion an heirloom of a long lost love; it’s all you can hold on to as you seek a haven in this hellish -yet beautiful- landscape. All you can do is move forward, and hope.

Proper story's suppose to start at the beginning’. Ain't so simple with this one.”
Perhaps the greatest strength of Bastion is its fantastic narration. The voice of the only survivor -and guide- in Caelondia
date: that follows your every step. The voice of Logan Cunningham is so deep
recommended: raw and powerful. It commands your attention as you explore
hoursPlayed: and battle the bygones of the Calamity.\n\nThat said
voteText: the narration is not the only factor that draws you in –it’s the beautifully designed landscapes

votesTotal: and the overwhelming feeling of loneliness. Though I felt “sad” reliving the loss and longing of the Kid

reviewText: Bastion is an action-RPG with some of the best art and one of the best soundtracks of this generation. The story even manages to be touching, thanks in no small part to the narration and soundtrack, which help you empathize with the characters and care about their stories.\n\nThere are lots of options for customizing your equipment and perks for different combat situations and, for those who want a more challenging experience, an in-game system for on-the-fly difficulty adjustment that provides a real challenge and not just scaled enemy hit points and damage. Whether you want to test your skill or just enjoy the view there's a setting for everyone. Expect around 10 hours for your first play through. Amazing game.

reviewText:
Bastion is a great example of what happens when a smaller, extremely talented studio really loves their product.  The voice cast and art style/soundtrack are some of the best I've experienced in gaming.  The mechanics also are extremely intuitive and fluid (outside of maybe the rolling but that might just be me. One wouldn't expect to become so attached to a story and characters in a game that started at only 20 USD, but by the end I guarantee you'll be suprisied with how you've fallen in love with them.  I got this game for about 2.00 USD, after playijng it I would gladly have paid full price.

In summary almost every aspect of this game is superb. Do yourself a favor and pick it up, you'll thank me later.

9/10

reviewText:
One of the best Indie games I've ever played. That is the best example for can be done without being an AAA title.
First, the story. The voice of the narrator was the first thing that baffled me. He describes everything (so no character voice), but it's in a unique, very fascinating way.

reviewText:
Well ladies and gents, it took me almost 5 years but I finally Beat the game with 8 hours on record. With that said I took this game pretty slowly and I still beat it in 8 hours, Just keep that in mind.
Let me just start off by saying this game is a work of Art, A Masterpiece. This game honestly shocked me, Before I knew who supergiant was, I went into this game thinking it was just some average indie game with little story. I thought that  you would just be  going from zone to zone grabbing these crystal shards until you finish the crystal. But slowly you start to realize it is not just that, you start to notice it is more complicated than that and encounter new characters and Items. As you get further and further into the game,the story starts getting thicker and thicker. The narrator (Who is absolutely fantastic by the way) Is pretty much telling someone the story of what you are doing in that moment and this mechanic is what helps guide you through some parts that you may not have figured out.
As you progress you get these items which you use at the Bastion to upgrade the weapons which adds some variation is play styles.
My only complaint is that the OPTIONAL dream levels took so long and there was no checkpoints so if you died on the last wave you would have to restart and redo the last 20 minutes over again.
9/10, excited to move on and play transistor finally!!

reviewText: Bastion is a truly incredible game.  While not a particularly long one, the depth of it lies in its beauty and story.  It stands out because of the artwork and the narration primarily, but many other aspects hold gamers captivated.  The music is wonderful and the various weapons are highly entertaining.  The narration was one of my personal favorite features.  Many games force you to sit through cut scenes or read massive amounts of text.  But the narration allows you to play without disturbances, and as it is sometimes subject to what you do in the game, it adds a level of humor.  It’s a beautiful game that I’ve played through multiple times (different account) and have yet to grow tired of.  The richness of the world created and the storyline lurking around every corner brings out the unique magic that Bastion holds.

reviewText:
One of the better soundtracks I've heard in a very long time, along with the Uncharted Series, Ori and the Blind Forest, and Skyrim. Combat is fluid, the levels are well designed, and let us not forget that guy narrating your every move. He's awesome.
I will also mention that this is one of the more beautiful games I've played in a long time, reminding me a lot of said Ori and the Blind Forest. It's bright, it's dynamic, and the colors always go with the levels flawlessly.

And this is all coming from less than an hour of gameplay.
I'll probably re-write this review later on, when I have more time in the game, but I have an inkling this will end up being one of the better games I've played in recent days, if not my life.

So, far, my first impression is %100 positive. Can't wait to see more of it.

reviewText:
Bastion is an isometric action RPG with a killer soundtrack.  You play as a kid living in a world torn apart by a mysterious, apocalyptic event called the Calamity whose best chance of survival lies with the Bastion.

The gameplay is pretty standard but the real attraction here is the story, which really picks up the pace around second act.  Logan Cunningham does a fantastic job as the narrator, providing the only voice you'll hear throughout your journey.

This game is a worthy buy at any price and you'd be doing yourself a disservice if you skip it.

reviewText:
8/10 - Beautiful game (visually as well as gameplay), really enjoyed it.

- Easy in overall difficulty with options to increase difficulty for bonus exp rewards (which can make it quite challenging)
- Plenty of balanced weapons that fit vastly different play styles

One complaint I do have about the game is the way that new weapons and skills are introduced: you receive new weapons in an un-upgraded form and are forced to play with a seemingly under-powered weapon.  After a hard time during the level due to the new weapon, you probably won't take it out for another spin.  This creates a bias for the starting weapons unless you really like to experiment.

reviewText:
Great little game, what is there more to say
I liked the soundtracks very much
I hope they'll get it on sale sometime (wasn't on sale at the same time as the game)
The narration feels pretty unique to me and rather good, I loved how the narrator comments on almost every single action making me feel like it's really my own story (he will comment differently based on your results and the little choices you make (even if in the end there is not much game altering choices that I know of so far but I have not finished the game yet)
I always feel compounded to get back to it and improve my bastion a little more.

I love the fact that you can dynamically alter the difficulty for more rewards, while it shortens some of the grinding,  the increased challenge is not something to be laughed at. Some upgrade path are not always straight damage/resistance increases or instead requires specific conditions which in my humble opinion makes the game more interesting.

My only regret would be that there is an optional built-in autoaim which is almost required for some challenges (at least it sure feels like it was balanced for players to use it and abuse it

column21: playable options that leave you feeling pleased as punch.\n\nThe art...is a blessing to the eyes. Unique
column22: painstakingly handpainted beauty with every step you take. A beautiful fusion of styles create an atmosphere unlike any other
column23: that seemlessly blends all aspects of the game together into a world that captures the imagination.\n\nLastly
column24: the characters and enemies are both enigmatic and relatable. Each character brings something powerful to the table
column25: allowing players to connect on an emotional level - something very difficult for many AAA titles to accomplish. Enemies are well-designed and entertaining
column26: leaving the player feeling ever-so-slightly guilty for their deaths...\n\nIn short
column27: absolutely the best indie game I have ever played
column28: and one of the greatest that I own. In no aspect does it fail to live up to the standards that every game should aspire to. I hope
column29: for the sake of your own experience and for the sake of the wonderful people who put so much love into making this game

reviewText:
It's short, so it's great for anyone with limited gaming time or attention spans.

The music is great, of course. I'd say the music was half of the enjoyment.

Lots of abilities and customizations to unlock, so you can choose your play style - melee, guns, arrows, etc.


The combat gets a little bit repetitive, and it's actually really easy. This is nice for people who don't like to rage, but I felt a little like I was just sort of walking through the story with how easy it was -- you can up the difficulty though, so that's fixable.


The story didn't really captivate me. I'm not sure why, it just wasn't very deep, so I didn't really come to care for/about the characters at all. There was one moment I felt moved, and that was at the ending, so at least it ends on a poignant note.

reviewText: Bastion's art-style looks really great and adds a lot to the feel of the game. The story is mostly shown to the player through the gameplay and environment rather than told in dialogue or text. This makes the story seem more interesting than it perhaps actually is. My favourite feature of Bastion is that as you make your way through the world, the story and landscape are described by a man who has the voice of an old, western heavy smoker. This constant commentary, whilst mostly ineffectual, really adds a lot to the game and makes discovering each new area and enemy that much more enjoyable.\n\nThe combat is fairly basic and very similar to other isometric hack & slashers and the game can be finished in just a few hours but I think that if it were longer it might out-stay it's welcome. Bastion is a great game and often appears in the steam sales so it is definitely worth picking up.

voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
*whistles a catchy tune from Bastion*

It could be any one of the beautiful songs from the soundtrack. ONE of them will stick in your head when you play this. If you're unlucky, more than one song will stick AND YOU WILL LOVE EVERY MINUTE OF IT.

...and if you thought the music was catchy, the gameplay and graphics will leave you wanting more. And if you play for the stories... well, you're going to love it. The combat can be adjusted so anybody can play it happily.

You want to play for the story? The No-Sweat mode will take the combat right down to the minimum. (My choice!)
You feel the urge to go a-la- Dark Souls? Normal mode with all shrines invoked will cause your character to die every few minutes unless you're a pro. (Don't say I didn't warn you!)

The graphics are cute, but never overly so. And no matter how cute the enemies, you WILL know they're enemies. No worries about bits of the background suddenly turning out to be a deadly boss without due warning. Only gripe in the whole game - one or two bits of scenery looked safe to walk on, even though they weren't.

tl;dr - BUY THIS, YOU WILL PROBABLY LOVE THIS FOR SOME REASON. STORY, GRAPHICS, SOUNDTRACK, GAMEPLAY, OR THE WHOLE THING. YOU WILL LOVE IT FOR SOMETHING.

reviewText:
A truly great game, unlike anything I've played before. An original and beautiful art style, captivating storyline with a stunning backstory, and satisfying the whole way through.

Progressing through the game, you find yourself being able to customize your character's unlockables to fit your playstyle and what you do best with, and the choice to upgrade what you want, when you want is great. If you pay attention to the lore that the amazing narration fills in for you, you'll be wholly immersed.

I just finished my first playthrough, and I know for a fact I'll enjoy replaying it with special rules and boundaries, finding new things I didn't catch the first time.

TL,DR: Buy this game! You won't regret it. (I swear on me nan!)

reviewText:
You play Kid who sets out on a mission to restore a land to which is once was. The story is what makes this one of my favorite arcade games. It is so immense and is unique is so many ways. This game extremely well done.

The artwork is fantastic and the gameplay is just astounding. The game mechanics are so great, they are fairly simple and easy to grasp hold of. The narrator for this game is extremely talented, his voice is so pleasant and fits the game perfectly.

The weapon system allows you make many weapon choices and combinations as well as certain and unique properties to go with those weapons. From a simple two handed hammer to what is basically a shoulder cannon that obliterates anything, the weapon system truly is amazing and fun to play around with. It also lets you choose between many traits as you progress in level. The game also provides mini challenges for each weapon which if you complete the assigned task you will rewarded with special items and secret moves for each weapon.

The characters in this game is also what dragged me into this amazing game. Each one of them, even the enemies, are unique in their own way and their diffifulcty can be increased through the use of Idols which give enemies new abilities or a boost in health, damage, or their mechanics during battle.

Another thing that I found neat about Bastion was that after you beat the game you can start the game from the beginning, but this time you will start out with the level your last playthrough, skills, weapons, and Idols. Overall this game is definitely a 10/10 for me.

reviewText: Bastion is a brawler from a top-down perspective with a cartoony look. I saw this game on sale, and I heard good things about it, so I decided to spend my hard earned 2 dollars on it. The game is not hard to run, it never crashed, the framerate did not decrease and it still manages to look very nice. Gameplaywise, the game is quite simple. You walk with the w, a, s and d, dodge with space, block with shift, which also locks on targets and aim and attack with the mouse. You can carry two weapons at once. There is a set of melee weapons and ranged weapons, which you unlock through the game. You can equip two melee weapons or two ranged weapons, but I mostly stick with one melee and one ranged. You attack with your primary weapon with left mouse button and secondary weapon with the right mouse button, and you attack in the direction you point with the cursor, unless you are targeting an enemy. But the targeting system seriously bugged me. I thought that pointing at the enemies was a little dumb, so I tried to target the enemies, but the targeting system seems to target enemies randomly, maybe it targets the enemy closest to the cursor, but I am not really sure. Anyway, back to the weapons. My favorites are the machete, hammer, pike, pistols and shotgun, but I hate the rifle and mortar, but the worst thing about this is that in some levels, you get a new weapon, and the game feels that you just have to try it out and half of the level is just a weapon tutorial, which I thought was kinda dumb. But you get the option to switch your weapons about halfway through, which is neat. Throughout the game, a narrator tells the story, and he has an awesome voice, but most of the time I cannot hear him, due to all the noises in the game, but you can mute the sound and turn the voice volume up, which helps. And the story is awesome, listen to it. The game takes about 5 hours to beat, not counting the optional weapon challenges, where you can win materials to further upgrade your weapons. There are also survival modes if you're in that kind of stuff. Anyway, I think Bastion was a pretty fun game, and it's cheap, too. I would say it's worth the money, even though it's kinda short and the game isn't perfect. And the soundtrack is for sale, too.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Bastion is one of the best games I have played and you have no excuse not to play it.

It combines a number of addictive elements that slowly get introduced to you. It has a witty narrator (think Stranger Than Fiction with Will Ferrell) that hilariously narrates everything you do. You get a few weapons along the way and a shield at the start then your favourite RPG tools appear.

Let’s talk about the graphics. Amazing! If you have a higher resolution screen like me (2560 by 1440), checkout the Steam discussions to get a fix for it (look in properties, set launch options… and add -x 2560 -y 1440). It’s like you have been thrown into an artist’s water coloured mind and has painted his brush all over your brain. The music and sounds are fantastic. This is truly what gaming is about.

Bastion is a hack and slash RPG, you get and upgrade weapons along the way, and you have secondary weapons, special attacks, weapon upgrade tree, elixirs to improve stats, shrine to increase difficulty and mini games to master your skills. Even after that, you have a nice loot system that you’re always trying to find and there’s an excitement level because when you get something, it’s good and not just worthless junk!

The only area I can really fault with this game is its story, it’s not as interesting like most games (I want to know what caused the Calamity, but that’s about it), it doesn’t even matter though. You just want to play and have a good time.

Best thing about Bastion is it always had something new to show the player, it’s not tedious, it doesn’t get stale. It’s refreshing to see a game excite so much while having so much strategy to a hack and slash genre which people tend to have a habit of mindlessly playing.

Thank you Bastion, for being awesome! One of my favourite games.

reviewText:
Have you ever played a game where you just wanted to play it because you wanted to listen to the pretty? If you haven't then you should play Bastion. The narrator is like earsex. Morgan Freeman wishes he had this voice.

Also, on the game's merits, I was surprised. No other game has had such varied one button gameplay. The weapons actually all play differently. Combine that with the fact that you can carry 2 weapons at a time and you've got incredible amounts of flexibility in how you want to play your game.

Solid ARPG stacked with an interesting story, beautiful voice acting, and plenty of play style flexibility makes this game a must buy. Plus, it can even be played in the chrome browser now. What is this technology madness?

Well worth the 15$, and if you're poor grab it on a sale. If you don't want to wait I'll even spot you a 5. This game is that good.

reviewText: Bastion is one of those indy titles that took the dedicated gaming community by storm, but it deserved to be so much more. reviewText:
**TOO LONG; DIDNT READ REVIEW SUMMARY** - This is a great Isometric Action Platformer that isn't done enough justice by a quick glance of screenshots or skimming of videos. It is one of the best games I have played in recent years.

Even if you don't enjoy many platformer games, there is too much about this game that is just excellent. The combination solid combat, interesting puzzles and exploration, great asthetics and setting, beautiful soundtrack, and excellent narration driving the story forward make for an enjoyable experience that can last 3-6 hours per run through the story. Short term replayability is limited, but long term, this game is good enough and stand well enough independent of story spoilers you can play it many times over the rest of your gaming career.

At it's full price, I can reccomend this game to most serious gamers, and any fan of action platformer games. At a sale price, often below $3, I can reccomend at least trying this game to every single person who plays games; it's that good.

Get this game.

-----------------------------------------------------------------

-----------------------------------------------------------------

-----------------------------------------------------------------

What Bastion is can be difficult to initially describe or grasp; and as such, escaped my interest for some time. When I finally did cave in and buy, I regret passing it over for so long.

I would best describe it's genre as an Isometric Action Platformer, with some RPG elements. reviewText:
I picked this up long ago and through a humble Bundle package, I had played it with the classic mouse / keyboard combination for a while but found it cumbersome. Though the directional keys allow you to navigate the maps decently, some aim and movement features in the game are just best done with an analog stick.

The game throws a plethora of weapon choices your way, from the usefull through the tactical up to the absurd; there's something for everybody here.

This game is defined by the soundtrack, that alone kept me playing.

The ending has impact, the replay mode gives you more freedom and the abillity to toughen up the enemies even more and the announcer is, semi-aware something fishy is going on. To go further into this would do the game a disservice.

Great game, best played with a controller; sadly no native XInput support, though x360ce does the job well.

reviewText: Before I actaully go into any sort of depth, for anyone that uses the Steam reviews of a game in the same way that I do, the game functions!  Some people have complained about the keyboard & mouse controls, but the controls were perfectly fine on a 360 controller.  Now, on to the review proper.\n\nBastion is a game where a mysterious calamity (simply called The Calamity" by survivors) has wiped out most of the world's population and shot most of the land into the air.  You play as a boy (simply called "The Kid")
date: and must traverse various different locations to find Cores
recommended: magical crystals that will help to rebuild The Bastion.\n\nOne of the first things that people will notice about the game is the unique way that the narrative is framed.  Many of the different things that you do in the game are accompanied by a narration.  The voice actor perfectly fits the Steampunk/western style of the game
hoursPlayed: and is an absolute joy to listen to
voteText: even though he is the only voice actor in the game (aside from a few of the songs that contain lyrics and a small amount of dialogue with another character at the end).  The narration is meant to be one of the characters in the game retelling of past events
helpfulPercent: occasionally foreshadowing something or giving his personal thoughts.  The game allows you to find out about the lore of the game and the backstories of the characters as if you were actually the person listening to the story
votesHelpful: allowing for you to decide what is true and what is made up.  Additionally
votesTotal: the beautiful handpainted graphics add to the atmosphere of the game in an incredible way.  You may end up feeling as if you don't want to kill any of the monsters
votesFunny: since they look so interesting
commentsCount: but avoiding them is generally not an option.  The game also explicitly mentions that many of the creatures used to be docile before The Calamity
column16: leaving it up to the player why they suddenly want to kill The Kid (at one point
column17: the narrator even says "At first they left the barge alone
column18: then they saw who was riding it.").\n\nStylings can only account for a part of the experience of playing a game
column19: though
column20: so on to the gameplay.  The game has a sort of hack-and-slash style to it
column21: and can feel very satisfying.  The weapons are all nicely varied
column22: allowing for many different choices
column23: and
column24: in addition
column25: each combination of two weapons elicits a unique line from the narrator.  The weapon upgrading system
column26: featuring the ability to switch between 2 paths (usually representing effects versus damage)
column27: and its feature of allowing the player to mix and match upgrades at a will
column28: adds even more depth.  Despite feeling satisfactory
column29: the combat can feel a bit too easy once you get the hang of it
column30: but learning each weapon as more are introduced throughout the game is great.  The "Proving Grounds
column31: of which there is one for each weapon, however, are a very nice challenge for the most part, and completing all of them is very rewarding, even if you as the player don't like to use the weapon that it's relating to.  The spirits that can upgrade your stats are a nice touch too, being a very unique way of upgrading and, again, eliciting a unique line of dialogue from the narrator whenever one is equipped, usually talking about its Pre-Calamity use or reputation.\n\nOf course, since the soundtrack of this game is so famous, I would be remiss to review it without mentioning the music.  The soundtrack in this game is possibly the best I've ever heard.  The area tracks fit perfectly with whatever kind of atmosphere that area wants to convey.  The musical cues are spot-on, and the few previously mentioned tracks (entitled Build That Wall"; "Mother I'm Here"; and "Setting Sail
column33: respectively) are indescribably wonderful.  Even while typing out this review, I'm listening to the soundtrack in the background.  It's THAT good, and I'd say definitely worth a look, even if you don't plan on playing the game.\n\nOn release, this game recieved major critical acclaim.  I have to say that, even though I only ever played it 3 years later, the game is wholly deserving of any and all praise.  It has, very occasionally, been accused of pretentiousness, and, to this, I have to say that a game being artsy" and it being "pretentious" are two very different things.  The handpainted backgrounds and incredible score add a level of atmosphere rarely seen in games.  The gameplay is very satisfying and rewarding

reviewText:
A perfect game. I didn't think much of this game before playing, but after I did I was amazed. Bastion is basically a top- down action RPG where you (as a boy) have to go around looking for shards to save the world.

The music is great and suits the game perfectly. You also have a neat selection of weapons to choose from such as a sword,hammer, musket etc. with unique upgrades to suit your playstyle. There are about 12-13 levels in this game which are all feel different from each other. Voice acting is also good as well. There are different game modes available such as survival and score attack and new game plus which add to some replayability to the game. Finally,the story is remarkable and something you will remeber for a while.

A problem I have with the game is the angles of some of the levels. I kept falling off because it was somewhat difficult to walk in a diagonal line in order to stay on some of the platforms. Another problem is that the direction your facing with the shield may not block all attacks as intended.

Should you buy it? Well, after playing the game for 16 hours (normal, new game plus  and all survival modes). I still have an urge to go back and play this game all over again.

reviewText:
Admittedly, I missed the Bastion hype train when it came chugging past in 2011 and had only ever heard of a brief description of it being 'good' from people around me. How I missed that goodness knows but after playing Bastion I can only say that it completely lives up to the hype around it.

In an action RPG hack and slasher, you play as a character simply called The Kid. What unfolds is a story where there is no 'good' or 'bad' but instead a morally grey area for a majority of the characters which leads to some interesting perspectives. The story is told by the narrator who comments and narrates almost everything you do as The Kid. Perhaps people can see this as being a gimmick for the game but I personally found it delightfully charming and enjoyed listening to the commentary as I played. It helps to try the story forward and serves as encouragement if you should get stuck to keep going. The only gripe I have about the story is that I would've liked to have a bit more of it, plus one of the decisions that you're forced to choose at the end doesn't seem to have much of an effect on the end story.

Graphically the game is stunning, even living up to the standards of 2014. Seeing the ground rise up around my character as I walked was stunning and helped to keep the pace of the game. Every area has been designed carefully so there's a lot to see and do in a story that is around 5 hours long. The foes you come up against have all had thought put into them and both move and look as I'd imagined.

Gameplay-wise the game is clever as it has an almost 'choose your own difficulty' with the shrine settings. By activating more idols  you gain bigger rewards but this in turn makes the game much more difficult. The use of the distillery also allows the player themselves to choose what bonuses they gain from levelling up making it so The Kid is completely customised to the player. The same goes with weapons; a range of melee and ranged weapons drop throughout the game which once again allows the player to play at their preferred style. This isn't something I'm used to seeing in games and it added to my enjoyment.

As for the soundtrack... it's honestly one of my favourite soundtracks and I'm someone who doesn't download soundtracks too much. It fits the mood of the game perfectly and  helps to immerse you straight into the world of Bastion. There's not much else I can say but I can guarantee that at the very least you should be able to fall in love with the soundtrack even if the game isn't for yourself.

The replay factor varies. I'm not the sort of person who'd play a game more than once yet I found myself playing Bastion for the second time through with the new gamemode I'd unlocked. As it allows you to carry over your stats and weapons from your previous save it makes the game a lot easier which some people may dislike but I enjoyed immensely. The game isn't so long that replaying it feels tedious either!

Ultimately I ended up being surprised that this game was made by an indie developer as it's so polished and such a beautiful, engaging game. There's not much I can fault other than one slight disgruntlement with the storyline to be honest. This comes highly recommended if there's anyone else who hasn't played it, even when it's not on sale. If it's on sale... well, there's no excuse to not buy Bastion.

reviewText: Fantastic game! Probably one of the best downloadable games i've played. The game's artstyle is consistant and fantastic to look at all the way through. The game's story whilst fairly simple is very engaging and leads to some great moments, with some good characters and special mention to the brilliant narration that drives the story foward and sounds oh so good. The music also deserves a special mention, with some truely memorable tracks that have a consistant tone throughout, with vocals being used at the right moments to make reveals and gameplay segments more effective and truly memorable. Gameplay is very fun with a vast array of weapons to try out and find which best suits your play style. I couldn't recommend this game enough, so if you're in the need for a fun and gorgeous looking indie game, this is the one to choose.

reviewText:
tl;dr 7/10 - Amasing music, story, and art. Definitely need to play Transistor afterwards though.

I think it's important to point out, that I played Transistor first (legit 10/10), and having heard this was much better, I went into Bastion with extremely high expectations; sadly it could not reach those expectations.

I found the conbat to be someone more hack n slash than the more planned out strategy found inTransistor. The level design, while more robust tan Transitors consistant color scheme, I kept falling off the edges of the map because it was not always clear what was floor and what wasn't...

That aside, Bastion is an amazing game with not only an amazing story, but characters that have a surprising level of depth, an amazing soundtrack, and art style that blew me away withi each new area.

reviewText:
Have you ever played a game where you just wanted to play it because you wanted to listen to the pretty? If you haven't then you should play Bastion. The narrator is like earsex. Morgan Freeman wishes he had this voice.

Also, on the game's merits, I was surprised. No other game has had such varied one button gameplay. The weapons actually all play differently. Combine that with the fact that you can carry 2 weapons at a time and you've got incredible amounts of flexibility in how you want to play your game.

Solid ARPG stacked with an interesting story, beautiful voice acting, and plenty of play style flexibility makes this game a must buy. Plus, it can even be played in the chrome browser now. What is this technology madness?

Well worth the 15$, and if you're poor grab it on a sale. If you don't want to wait I'll even spot you a 5. This game is that good.

reviewText:
My first experience of the Kid waking up in Bastion instantly told me that this was going to be one of those games that you don’t forget, something truly special. So let me preface this by saying I will try and make my review as spoiler-free as possible.

You wake alone amidst serene chaos, on an island of beautifully painted pieces suspended over a seemingly infinite void. The only accompaniment is the deep, gravelly, and reassuring voice of the Narrator. Moving from your bed, the world begins to form at your feet. Tiles zip up to form a path before you, leading you onwards through a vibrant, colourful environment.

At it's core, Bastion is a competent action RPG. You can carry two weapons (each with a unique role, ability and all upgradeable), as well as a shield (which when used at the correct time allows you to deflect) and a special ability. While there is nothing particularly genre-redefining here, it fulfils its function and allows you to dodge and roll through the world slashing and shooting at lot’s of enemies as well as collecting “shards”, fragments of the old world.

Not being a huge fan of ARPG’s myself, the real draw of the game for me was the delivery of the story, the atmosphere and the whole mystery surrounding the world. You want to know what happened here. The primary way for you to find out is through the Narrator.

The way Bastion utilises the Narrator works phenomenally well. He leads you through the levels, depositing slivers of story as well as beautifully crafted nuggets of feedback of your play style, all in a unique style of speech that you will associate with his long after the credits roll. Decide to smash everything in the room? Expect to hear something along the lines of “Kid just rages for a while”. Your character, the Kid, is a silent protagonist. But this is allows you to focus entirely on the Narrator, whose ability to drop subtle undertones of dismissal or hints at a haunted past is astonishing.

Difficulty is handled in an ingenious way as well. Instead of just a straight Easy/Medium/Hard slider, you can choose to make the game more difficult in different ways through a building that I would rather not spoil. Not only does it allow the game to be more tailored to how much you want to be challenged, it does it through a totally natural system that doesn't take you out of the experience.

It isn’t without complaints though. The isometric camera angle can cause some frustration when coupled with the inherent limited maneuverability of the WASD keys. If this is getting too much for you, a 360 pad can be used instead. A small complaint, but worth mentioning.

The music for the game is also something else. Trust me when I say this, you should get a hold of the soundtrack. The melding of instruments from different cultures and technology creates a sound that fits the game’s theme like a glove. The way it is used in one particular song sent shivers through me.

So in summary, while the core of the gameplay is not hugely inspired (though sufficiently refreshed to be enjoyable) and the isometric view and keyboard limitations can be stifling, the game is one that should be celebrated as an achievement in the medium. The story and its implementation through the Narrator, the world in all its desolate beauty and the extraordinary soundtrack all come together. Each element melds to create an audio and visual treat which should not be missed.

reviewText: The game itself seems like it would have been done before, but the difference is in the pacing and visibly the art. The game feels amazing as every attack, hit, and evade your character does is important to the way you want to play. And speaking of playing, the different weapons in the game offer outstanding gameplay changes. You want to be able to run up to some one and slash as fast as you can? Sure, pick the machete. You want to smash stuff doing tuns of damage in as few hits as possible? Got your big ♥♥♥ hammer right here. I don't think I need to go into how good the narration and soundtrack is. A really good experience overall. Worth the 14.99 (at the current moment of this post). Pick it up whenever you feel like all your other games are stale.

reviewText:
A brilliant Isometric Action Platformer subtly masked as a narrative story where your actions build the world around you.

The music is deep and soulful adding a lot to the player immersion.
If you're a fan of voice acting and active narration (Battleblock Theatre) then this game will be a treat- the story is told aloud as you progress and changes when you make choices.

There's a lot of difficult battles, not quite a Gauntlet style Battle Arena, more like Robotron/Smash TV's dual stick movement and firing system and several augments and weapons to choose from to customize to your play style.

Can be difficult to pick up without a controller though playing with M/K is not impossible. Played through my first time with M/K and would not go back to them after using a 360 controller.

Varying difficulty settings and optional weapon mastery challenges make it so this game has a lot of obstacles to overcome for us players. The difficulty ramps very steadily from the beginning to end and is completely possible to master the game with a little patience and practice with the weapons that suit your playstyle.

Definitely an achievement hunter friendly game.

Worth playing, worth beating, worth 100%ing.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
8/10 - Beautiful game (visually as well as gameplay), really enjoyed it.

- Easy in overall difficulty with options to increase difficulty for bonus exp rewards (which can make it quite challenging)
- Plenty of balanced weapons that fit vastly different play styles

One complaint I do have about the game is the way that new weapons and skills are introduced: you receive new weapons in an un-upgraded form and are forced to play with a seemingly under-powered weapon.  After a hard time during the level due to the new weapon, you probably won't take it out for another spin.  This creates a bias for the starting weapons unless you really like to experiment.

reviewText: A fantastic example of a GOOD style-driven game - the best I've played maybe since the first Viewtiful Joe. (Note: This is somber, not bombastic like VJ. Just so you don't get the wrong idea.) There's some balance issues which make the customization a little less than it could be, but there's enough viable options that you won't mind. Solid Zelda-Style combat and lots of atmosphere. It would be too short as a full-priced game, but it's all quality, and at this price it's a bargain. If you have a weekend to kill and like listening to vaguely philosophical drawls in westerns, then you can't go wrong with Bastion.

reviewText: My favorite game of 2011! I love how you're constantly getting new weapons till the very end and how they each have a very different feel. And the system for constantly retuning their upgrades gave a lot of tactical decision making possibilities that changed how you use them. The flow of combat with timed shots, blocking, parries, and dodges is so well done... at least once you learn all those tricks from the training challenges. The passive upgrades and self imposed difficulty modifiers for bonus XP were really cool too (especially after they add more on the second play through).\n\nTo top it off there's the beautiful music, visuals, and narration. Everything came together in to such an awesome package. Can't wait for their next game!

reviewText: Truly a work of art. You can find lots of games with similar combat but few, if any, could rival Bastion's art direction or narrative.  Has multiple endings. I'll probably replay it on New Game + in order to experience it. I definitely reccomend picking this game up at some point if you are interested in a good narrative. reviewText: Bastion is one of those indy titles that took the dedicated gaming community by storm, but it deserved to be so much more. Thinking back on the more than 30 hours I sunk into the campaign and challenges of this game, I can't come up with a single fault. The art style is beautiful, the combat is simple but robust and at the more difficult stages becomes shockingly deep. The story is very well written and concieved; but dear god the narration. The narration in this game is a thing of absolute beauty. And if for no other reason, everyone should play through this game just to see how powerful well designed narration can be.\n\nBuy this game and play it all the way through, you won't be disappointed.

reviewText:
My God, I've just finished this game and I have no words to describe how hilarious it is. Maybe it's just me, and this game suits me well, but I've had one of the most awesome experiences in my gamer-life. Mostly it's thanks to the story - smooth and perfect, it slowly unfolds before your eyes. The ending touches, but I won't be relling a word not to accidentally spoil someone's gaming experience.
The second awesome thing is soundtrack. My Goodness, how I loved it! One day I've caught myself humming one of the motives during the working day - and than's when I realized i was in love with it. So grammophone was just another piece of game for me, perfect in itself.
The other aspects of this hilarious game were also leaving only positive impressions - battle system, weapons upgrade system, spirits, special ablities, shrines with varying difficultie through the game, pets (omg, Squirt was sooo qute!) and so on. Of course the draphic design - the style is just complementing the whole picture, creating the masterpiece.
So, if you ask me, I would completely reccomend this game to everyone who loves game with strong breathtaking stories.

reviewText:
You play Kid who sets out on a mission to restore a land to which is once was. The story is what makes this one of my favorite arcade games. It is so immense and is unique is so many ways. This game extremely well done.

The artwork is fantastic and the gameplay is just astounding. The game mechanics are so great, they are fairly simple and easy to grasp hold of. The narrator for this game is extremely talented, his voice is so pleasant and fits the game perfectly.

The weapon system allows you make many weapon choices and combinations as well as certain and unique properties to go with those weapons. From a simple two handed hammer to what is basically a shoulder cannon that obliterates anything, the weapon system truly is amazing and fun to play around with. It also lets you choose between many traits as you progress in level. The game also provides mini challenges for each weapon which if you complete the assigned task you will rewarded with special items and secret moves for each weapon.

The characters in this game is also what dragged me into this amazing game. Each one of them, even the enemies, are unique in their own way and their diffifulcty can be increased through the use of Idols which give enemies new abilities or a boost in health, damage, or their mechanics during battle.

Another thing that I found neat about Bastion was that after you beat the game you can start the game from the beginning, but this time you will start out with the level your last playthrough, skills, weapons, and Idols. Overall this game is definitely a 10/10 for me.

reviewText: Boy started up this game.  He knew it was good, but he didn't know what he was getting into.  Inside was a colorful world, a world that hid its sinister side. reviewText: I originally played Bastion on Xbox, but it was good enough for me to buy again during a Steam sale!\n\nThe thing that Bastion does right that so many other games seem to forget is that audio is a big part of a game. reviewText:
Bastion is a game that after about 10 minutes of play is obviously a game designed for smartphones. You can tell by the way everything handles and the flow of combat. That being said, after about 30-40 minutes of play you likely either don't notice anymore or don't care. There are some games you get for the story and the art moreso than the gameplay; Bastion is certainly one of those games, but the gameplay doesn't really let you down either.

There is a fine selection of weapons, power-ups, and challenge arenas. If you just want to run through the story, enjoy the fine voice-acted narration, and then call it a day you can. Or you can bust your butt and try to unlock everything, but at no point did it feel to me like doing busy work; I always felt adequately rewarded for my time. It's the coffee table reading equivalent of a game in that you can play it in 20 minute intervals and always feel like you're getting somewhere, which for me is an invaluable game to have on hand at all times. Yes, I like the long quests, but sometimes I just wanna sip some coffee and game a bit before getting to work on something.

New Game+ grants you the ability to build on previous progress, but this is a story that when it ended I really wanted to know what would happen next. And that's almost a perfect ending. You get a host of weapons, liquor-based powerups, relics, cultures, history, gods, challenge modes, and then at the end really all you want more of is the storyline; not because the story provided was poor but because it was so good that you hate giving those characters up to the void of what we cannot know (unless they release a sequel).

reviewText: By the end of this game I have to admit, I was getting a little tired of the gameplay. It wasn't necessarily boring because the game steadily throws new weapons and enemies at you which you have to work your head around. But by the end, I was mostly looking forward to not having to see another one of those green eyed thorn balls. I've never been a big fan of dungeon crawlers, so maybe it's a point in Bastion's favour that it was able to keep me interested for so long despite my mixed feelings towards the gameplay.\n\nThe artwork is definitely the highlight of the game. The landscapes are bring and colourful, and it's a plearsure to meaner your way throught them. The sound is great, with parts of the landscape giving a satisfying cruch" when they're destroyed. And the voice acting... oh man. Rucks is the narrator/guide through your adventure. He is well written
date: and his rusty voice gives the game a lot of character. Buy the Bastion announcer pack in Dota 2 if you want more.\n\nOverall
recommended: it's a good game. I won't be playing it over
hoursPlayed: but it was overall an enjoyable game while it lasted. I'll be looking forward to playing Transistor next."

reviewText: Bastion is an action adventure game with a few RPG elements. The gameplay is dynamic, and very entertaining; art style is cartoonish, colorful, haflfway anime but not overdone. OST is one of the best I've heard and it's perfectly used through the game fitting each moment's pace completely. These things would already make the game outstand, yet it's major strenght is story and narrative. You can easily immerse into the story by hearing the narrator as you advance through the game, story unfolds with each step you take. It has only a few or no drawbacks, the only I can think of is it's relatively short duration (6-7 hrs) and that the ending didn't wrap everything up as I would like.\nFinal veredict: Brillant 9,3/10. Totally recommended.

reviewText:
tl;dr 7/10 - Amasing music, story, and art. Definitely need to play Transistor afterwards though.

I think it's important to point out, that I played Transistor first (legit 10/10), and having heard this was much better, I went into Bastion with extremely high expectations; sadly it could not reach those expectations.

I found the conbat to be someone more hack n slash than the more planned out strategy found inTransistor. The level design, while more robust tan Transitors consistant color scheme, I kept falling off the edges of the map because it was not always clear what was floor and what wasn't...

That aside, Bastion is an amazing game with not only an amazing story, but characters that have a surprising level of depth, an amazing soundtrack, and art style that blew me away withi each new area.
